review_title: Size Matters
review_detailed_main: The overall view of This movie by film critics and Godzilla purists is that it is bad. Very bad. It sounds like this movie was almost unwatchable by the world. But to a twelve year old boy with no idea about previous Godzilla films living in the middle of upstate NY in 1998, this film was great! Seeing this in theaters was a fun experience as a kid. Pretty sure since they made an animated series and plenty of Godzilla toys and figures and merchandise that this movie was made for kids like me. As an adult rewatching I can see the things that people criticize about the film but that just makes it funny. Like understanding an adult joke in a kids movie once you're older. Super inappropriate but another sign of how times have changed. I would definitely recommend this movie for for older kids and adults looking for a laugh or to unwind. I would not recommend this to people studying film or people who feel strongly about the lore of Godzilla.

review_title: Possibly the worst movie ever made.
review_detailed_main: Any human who actually took the time to rate this movie and not give it a 1 must have been smoking large quantities of crack immediately before they voted. I would rather have my eyelids removed than sit through this movie again. I hope the corporation that made this movie is very happy with all the money they've made.

review_title: What was wrong with this movie? (WARNING: MAY contain a Spoiler)
Not too shabby...
review_detailed_main:
The 1998 first American attempt at bringing Gojira, aka Godzilla, to the screen was actually not a bad attempt. Sure, there was something campy about it, because Gojira is a Japanese phenomena through and through, but director Roland Emmerich managed to pull it off fair enough.

The storyline in "Godzilla", as written by Dean Devlin, Ted Elliott, Terry Rossio and Roland Emmerich, is a pretty straightforward one. It definitely isn't rocket science, nor did it have to be to be entertaining. "Godzilla" is a popcorn movie, no doubt about that, and that is what works so well about it.

The cast ensemble in the movie was good, with the likes of Matthew Broderick, Jean Reno, Hank Azaria, Kevin Dunn, Michael Lerner, Harry Shearer and Doug Savant.

Visually then "Godzilla" is good. The CGI effects look good and does help to make the movie all the more enjoyable.

My rating of "Godzilla" lands on a six out of ten stars. A good first American attempt, but you just can't beat the Japanese original.

review_title: Awful is too nice for this one...
review_detailed_main:
Godzilla is so bad you will cry and ask anyone near you to kill you before the end of this movie! This horror will make you want to make voodoo dolls from the director of this insult to everything the word movie stands for! Is the message clear? If it isn't, I can explain to you why it is so bad... First of all, this was to be a movie you could watch just for fun. Believe me, it is NOT fun. In fact, it's even boring. The action scenes are inspired(I am nice) by the Jurassic Park movies. This movie could have at least been impressive in terms of special effects... IT IS NOT! They are barely okay! The characters are not important in this movie, but they sure are bad! Maria Pitillo should get an award for worst AND most annoying performance in an easy role to play. She has crossed the line that separates bad from awfully bad! Jean Reno is a very good actor, but he has such a boring character he can't make him believable! It goes in my rating than such bad movies as Twister, Batman and Robin and the second Jurassic Park!!!

1 out of 10!!! It's a long,boring and almost actionless action movie!

review_title: If only computers would render plot and originality too...
review_detailed_main: ....because this movies plot and originality don't get any worse. (Is the fx technology ruining the movie industry instead of improving it?) Technologically, it's a must see. Plot quality wise? Sad. The original writer who had been inspired by some sadistic power-that-be to write the original Godzilla and torment the Japanese movie going audience, will be very happy. Because the remake totally compares to that, and the other several thousand Japanese Godzillas which are forever doomed to remain untouched on Video clubs' shelves and be broadcasted by state television in third world countries. Imagine what the sequel will be like. Yuck.

review_title: somehow manages to be cheesier than the original series
This Godzilla is fun and entertaining, though borders on comedy. it's Jurassic Park meets The Gremlins.
review_detailed_main:
I love the origin and the mutation of iguanas through nuclear testing. The set up is intriguing, but Godzilla would never "hide" in New York City.

I like the characters and the monster is great, though it isn't the King of Monsters. It is an afraid mutation that is trying to understand how to adapt in this world. He actually climbs on top of a building, King Kong style and cries.

If this movie had not been a Godzilla movie it would have been rated better with fans.

Perhaps The Attack of the Giant Iguana: (you mess with nature and it'll bite you in the but!)

review_title: Where's Ghidora and Gamera?
review_detailed_main:
Isn't Godzilla (alongside some kid or group of kids) supposed to be the hero of the film? With the exception of this and the first film, Godzilla is the pseudo-savior of Tokyo. Albeit, while he levels half the city, he is always doing it to defeat the real villains or monsters. This film didn't have that. Heck, there is only one or two Japanese people in the entire film.

Real Godzilla films have the following...

~Godzilla is breathes radioactive fire. ~Godzilla never actually intends to destroy the city. It is always a side effect of his fighting the monsters that want to destroy the city.

~The movies are always based in Japan, primarily Tokyo.

~Godzilla fights other monsters. These other monsters (Ghidora, Megalon, space Godzilla) are the real bad guys.

This film did not have any of that. Part of the whole appeal of the real Godzilla films is the cheaper graphics, the man in a lizard suit, poorly dubbed voices, and NO Americans. (I don't hate us, it's just that we have a tendency to want things our way only)

Let's face it, the only thing really going for this was the clean look of the film.

And as a final thought, why DID Godzilla go to New York? (New York belongs to King Kong) Why didn't he go for Los Angeles or Seattle? Both are closer to the south pacific.

Verdict: Godzilla belongs in Tokyo, facing other monsters, whilst destroying parts of Japan. This film is not a Godzilla film. It's sci-fi film that resembles Godzilla films.

review_title: 20 Years late, but finally watched
review_detailed_main:
Not really a review, just an opinion from seeing it 20 years after it was released. I never cared too much to see it as I thought it looked a little fake from the previews that I saw back in the day (although I did buy the soundtrack back then for the songs). Decided to watch it and although I cringed at a lot of parts - some of the direction, sometimes the acting or the dialogue that was written, plus a lot of the CGI - there was a lot that could have been better. It wasn't a good story. The CGI wasn't great, even for the time. Character interactions were shocking at times. But, I still found myself watching to the end and I had a good time.

The more recent 2014 Godzilla was outstanding in my opinion and this '98 mo ie does not touch that. But, I just viewed it as an over-hollywoodised monster film and just enjoyed it as a B-Grade movie in a better budget. That way I could laugh in some places.

I don't really recommend the film. But it wasn't a total disaster. It really did remind me of how a lot of films were done in the 90's - the style in which they wrote I mean. We've come a long way.

review_title: The Lizard Man?
review_detailed_main: Total trash. Blasphemy of the highest order. This doesn't even qualify as a Godzilla movie in my opinion. Who thought this was a good idea?

review_title: Nostalgia & Fun
review_detailed_main:
I saw this at the cinema when it came out.

I thought it was great, back in 1998.

Just re watched and I can understand why some may not like it, however I feel it's a bit of an overlooked gem of the 90s. Light weight but enjoyable.

Many familiar faces... and voices.

This is a great movie to watch on a rainy day or night.

Godzilla is T Rex like and the whole vibe is Jurassic Park like.

I recommend you give it a watch and give it a chance.

This was a big deal when it came out and still holds up pretty well. A lot to like and not much to dislike... it's very well made and well paced. Nothing more, nothing less.

review_title: Burn $10, you'll have more fun.
review_detailed_main:
Lord, what an awful movie.

I tried. I really, really, really tried to like "Godzilla." I went into it telling myself, "It's just a summer blockbuster. Don't expect it to be something it's not. Just accept it on its own terms and enjoy it." And as the previews started rolling, I honestly thought I could at least not hate it.

But lord, what an awful movie.

In a movie like this, the special effects are supposed to be the driving force. Let's just say that we've seen the same effects, and better, elsewhere ("Jurassic Park" comes to mind pretty fast). Once you lose those, there isn't all that much else. The dialogue is laughable, the performances are tremendously wooden, and the cutesie cameos and bits elicit more groans than grins.

Forget "wait-for-video", this movie is "wait-for-it-to-be-two-for-a-buck-at-Wal-Mart."

review_title: My first favorite movie, actually. I was seven.
review_detailed_main:
In between the post-Hiroshima anxiety of Gojira (1954) and the retributive-Gaia wonder of Godzilla (2014) there lies this Roland Emmerich disaster film, appropriately adapted to his action/comedy intensive priorities.

Now let's talk about Zilla or GITO (Godzilla in Name Only). Creature designer Patrick Tatopolous (sound familiar?) was aware that Jan de Bont's cancelled Godzilla film had been rejected in-part because of disagreements with Toho concerning the character concepts. Tatopolous distanced his design from Toho's and De Bont's mostly out of his respect for the original Japanese monster. This distance pays off, visually. A problem I'd long had with Tsuburaya's monster was (relative realism considered) just how bottom-heavy he is. GITO is much more mobile than old Thunder-Thighs, which properly matched Emmerich's vision of a high-speed chase with a titanic reptile.

Any Emmerich fan can at least appreciate the ways that this film avoids simply trying to one-up an already established cinematic mold.

review_title: Enjoyable film of its type.
review_detailed_main: Follows more or less traditional pattern of monster movie. Enbjoyable even though you know the good guys (we humans) will win out in the end, and the romantic aspect will be resolved suitably. Good-natured poking fun at a lost of familiar targets. A bit too long, in my opinion, but not for fans of the genre. Last scene with new monster being hatched there, i suppose, to allow for sequel, but still a kind of he (it)-who- laughs last laughs.

review_title: I thought it was never going to end!
review_detailed_main: Spare yourself the waste of time. This movie seems to never end. They kill Godzilla, then there's more. They kill them, and then it ends with still more Godzillas. Terrible!

review_title: My pick for the worst movie ever.
review_detailed_main:
I felt compelled to post a review of this movie after reading some other reviews that referred to it as, "Not that bad."

It IS that bad, and worse. From the terrible plot, riddled with inconsistencies, to the acting (everyone) which made my fourth grade's production of The H.M.S. Pinafore seem Tony award-worthy, to the dialogue which was inane when supposedly serious and pathetic when supposedly funny, this film sets a new standard for drivel.

The special effects are ok, but come nowhere close to saving this film. If you want to see good special effects, there are literally hundreds of movies you should spend time watching rather than this one.

If you are thinking of renting this movie, do not. In fact, if you come across the package for this movie sitting on the shelf in the rental store, turn around and run as fast as you can in the opposite direction and pray that you did not get close enough for the aura of black energy emanating from the box to poison your soul.

This was the only movie for which I have ever left the theater before it was over. I left at the very end -- I didn't want to walk out after the theater lights came on and run the risk of being recognized.

review_title: Godzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzila
Not as bad as you might think
utterly, miserably, awful
review_detailed_main: Inept, bumbling, stupid, asinine. The worst movie I have seen at a theater in my life, and the first one I walked out of halfway through. Only the comic-relief Frenchmen were at all interesting or funny; the rest was merely deeply, deeply stupid and implausible even for a silly monster movie. Either the writers were brain-dead, or brain-dead directors and producers ignored most of what they wrote and substituted their own drivel. Not even so-bad-it's-good...no redeeming virtues whatever. Didn't work on any level, not as monster flick, spoof, anything at all.

review_title: A Fun Underrated Monster Movie
review_detailed_main:
Godzilla (1998) is an entertaining monster movie as long as you treat it as a film on its own and not relate it back to the other Godzilla movies. I saw Godzilla when I was a kid and was not familiar with the original films. I just saw this film by itself and had a good time. It has some good effects and good action. I did like some of the characters too. Matthew Broderick I think does a good job. He gets a lot of hate, but I did not mind him. I also like Jean Reno who plays the French soldier named Philippe. There are several problems, but I did ultimately enjoy the film.

The plot is quite simple. Due to nuclear testing from the French one lizard mutated into a giant creature that comes to be known as Godzilla and is wreaking havoc across the globe until it finally reaches New York. The military enlist a scientist named Dr. Niko (Matthew Broderick) to help them stop the monster. Meanwhile the French military work under the radar to stop the creature in an attempt to make-up for their mistake.

I already stated the things I really like about the film. I like the effects including the design of Godzilla. Many people hate the design but I like it. I like the action scenes, especially the ones in the nest. I also like Matthew Broderick and Jean Reno's characters. However, the film also has things I do not like. Firstly, I do not like Audrey, who is Niko's love interest. She comes off as annoying and unnecessary. The same can be said for her fiends Victor the camera man and his wife Lucy. They also come off as annoying and useless to the overall story. They are just the comic relief that was not that funny.

Secondly I do not like how seemingly incompetent the military seems to be here. They attempt to take on Godzilla in the middle of the city which they can easily kill countless people and cause much collateral damage, which is exactly what they do. In fact, the military causes more destruction than Godzilla half the time. They cannot seem to land a hit on Godzilla with all their firepower even though he is the size of a skyscraper. Not-to-mention Godzilla gives them the slip on multiple occasions despite his size. A lizard the size of a skyscraper should not be that hard to spot.

Overall, Godzilla is a fun action/monster popcorn movie. It has good effects for the time, great action scenes, and a couple decent characters. There are several moments that require you to suspend your disbelief. But if you can you should be fine. If you do not compare this to the original Godzilla films you should have a good time.

review_title: Maybe it did some good
review_detailed_main:
I watched this thing on video because i felt incomplete not having seen this monster (of a) movie until now. I now feel like it was a waste of time..

It just drags on and on with poor dialogue, flat undeveloped characters, bad acting (Broderick is detestable), over-used special effects and the lack of a plot whatsoever.

Let's pray nobody picks up the idea of creating another one of these monstrous cult remakes.

review_title: A Bad Goji Film, But A Good Gino One IMHO
review_detailed_main:
Gino (Godzilla In Name Only) gets his time to shine in this fairly entertaining American Kaiju flick. This is a rather lackluster effort as a Godzilla film, but Gino is a pretty cool monster in his/her own right and this is passable entertainment.

All-in-all a solid American monster flick that is disappointing if viewed as part of the Godzilla series.

review_title: Run for the exits!
review_detailed_main: The best part of Godzilla was the trailer for 'Blade' at the beginning. After saying that, I'll summarize some more. If you want to watch something more interesting then this movie, do the following. Go buy a pet iguana and put him on your living room floor and watch him walk around. Instant hollywood movie material. What a joke this film was. Too bad Broderick had to be part of it. How can he go from Wargames, Ferris, and Glory to this? That sux. :(

review_title: Movie = 8 out of 10 . . . Continuity = 2 out of 10
Unrealistic and dumb, but not quite as bad as they say
Emmerich the auteur?,no, Emmerich the amateur!
review_detailed_main: I saw this film when it was first released ,a couple of years ago.Unfortunately time hasn't faded the awfulness of it.Roland Emmerich is not a director,he's a conveyer belt assembler! Godzilla is worse than Indepedence Day.Any film,no matter how unbelievable it's storyline can suspend your disbelief in the right hands.This film was in the wrong hands big time.The "Yeah...but it's only a flick" answer doesn't hold up.For the obscene amount of money put into this bloated mess,you would at least think they would try a hell of a lot harder!For an example ,check out "Gorgo" a 1961 british film,or a dozen others.

review_title: Couldn't be further from the truth
review_detailed_main:
Ok, I think we are missing something here. Wasn't Godzilla supposed to be the good guy. The big lizard that saved Tokyo more than once when the people were in trouble. So why not has Godzilla suddenly become the bad guy. I just don't get it. It's probably the army's habit of treating anything they don't understand as a national threat and want to destroy it.

Highlights of the movie were the street chases through Manhattan. You got the army throwing everything they got at Godzilla and not even a scratch, they even lost some of their own men and weapons. And they went and did it again! Gives new meaning to military intelligence. And since when can a torpedo lock on to organic material. Great move evading those torpedoes Godzilla.

review_title: One of Hollywood's most expensive sci-fi B-movies?
Okay... but it's not the Godzilla I grew up with
review_detailed_main: I have nothing against the movie. The action and special effects are pretty good for 1998. Some of the acting is ok. My main problems are some of the choice of actors (two of them are veteran voice actors from The Simpsons), the change of origin to Godzilla, and his redesign. However, despite its flaws, it's still somewhat enjoyable.

review_title: What is this?
review_detailed_main:
This ain't a movie, it's a commercial!

Well it seems to be new way of making a movie: "SPECIAL EFFECTS" There is no room anymore for real acting, I guess. :(

During the movie I fell in sleep. That never happened to me before.

I will say, stay away from this movie, FOREVER!!!

review_title: Flawed but very entertaining, interesting, awesome and fun to watch
Not the worst movie ever.
review_detailed_main:
"From the makers of Independence Day".

That line tells that this movie is probably not going to be very good. I wasn't disappointed. It was almost worse than ID4. And that's an accomplishment.

The movie felt like a combination of "JP2: Lost World" and "Aliens" arranged in the manners of ID4. I'm amazed at how much of ID4 we can see in this one. The main character could be the same guy basically. A forgotten scientist who gets drawn into the big events. He's still in love with his long-gone girlfriend. By the end of the movie they get together again. (btw, that annoyed me as hell! I really hated that girl, he should've chosen the other one).

I don't think the acting was very bad. There were many good actors in the movie. They just had a bad script.

The basic idea of the movie is not a bad one. I like the concept of "Huge Godzilla-monster goes downtown New York". You could do something very interesting with that. But it's sad to see that idea drowned in moronic characters (the french somewhat excluded) and drama effect after drama effect. The dramatic effects should support the story and not the other way around.

review_title: It is not a review
review_detailed_main:
It is not a review but it was my first Godzilla movie The Godzilla movie were a part of my childhood, fueling my imagination and love for epic battles. I vividly remember sitting in front of the TV, completely captivated by the giant monster's roar and the destruction it left in its wake. It wasn't just about the action-it was the thrill of watching humanity face seemingly unstoppable forces. Those moments of awe and excitement bonded me with my friends and family, sparking endless discussions and even inspiring my childhood drawings and stories.

1998 was a good year to me Thanks alot for reading till now bye bye.

review_title: Wow. This Really Sucks!
review_detailed_main:
What more can you say?

Acting - Bad. Plot - Stupid. Dialogue - Worst.

The only positives are the great special effects...

but even effects-laden blockbusters like "Jurassic Park" (which this is striving badly to be like) had a plot.

I rate this movie 10 stinky fish out of ten.

review_title: Anyone who doesn't like this movie is wrong.
review_detailed_main: I don`t know what people expected from this movie. High drama, perhaps Shakespearean dialog. This is an all out action movie that deserves way better reviews than it got. This movie could have been horrible, but the characters were pretty well fleshed for a movie of this type, and the makers actually went for the pathos angle with the creature. Rather than make Godzilla a giant monster, they gave the creature a personality with its behaviour, a personality that can best be seen at the Madison Square Garden explosion. For anyone to not find that scene poignant, they must be heartless. Add to this the great acting, and the "scientific" explanations (which was more than Independence Day ever managed) and this is a grossly under-rated movie.

review_title: So silly
review_detailed_main: I actually enjoyed this movie but having watched it again 2019 I have to say the years have not been kind to this movie it's just a silly movie

review_title: yeeeeeeeeeeeeuuuuch!
review_detailed_main:
So bad, it's even hard to review! Two questions: why the hell did Toho allow this mess? And: are we sure they

did spend more than 100M $ to craft this below average piece of moviemaking? SFX were crappy, acting poor (and no Big Buck names were involved), and the entire Madison Square Garden Velociraptor-like sequence stinks. Furthermore, there's

too much advertising and in-Jokes like major Ebert (thumbs down!) are silly beyond forgiveness. American audiences should be angry with Emmerich. He's a heavy teutonic iconoclast revanchist: it seems he only gets pleasure out of destroying the country. At one point I thought the Army was going to defeat Godzilla with another 1,000 H-Bombs like they did in ID4! can you imagine the sequel? The lizard's carcass slowly rotting in the background and Matthew Broderick as well as millions of new yorkers slowly dying of cancer.....

review_title: Bad but a Future Classic
review_detailed_main: There are so many flaws in this movie it's terrific. You actually lose count. Noise level is constantly high. Nearly the whole movie was shot in the dark at night. The army blows up more buildings than Godzilla destroys, etc. I don't want say more.

review_title: Worst Godzilla Movie Ever
Living proof that hype can kill.
review_detailed_main:
I went into this movie with fairly low expectations, having endured a year of hype followed by 2 months of bad press. Although it was by no means good, it was nowhere near as bad as I expected. The flaws, though huge, should have been obvious and easy to fix : total lack of suspense buildup in the beginning, some truly awful dialogue (Matthew Broderick isn't a bad actor but anyone seeing him here for the first time would think he was retarded), Maria Pitillo, and the fact that Godzilla is cast as a victim rather than a menace. So instead of feeling like the good guys kicked butt and killed the evil monster, you feel like the good guys weren't so good and killed a big, but essentially harmless creature. During the best scene in the movie (the helicopter chase) I was cheering for Godzilla!

Broderick's character was a problem - his feelings about Godzilla were never clear and he was far too wimpy to be the hero.

Ultimately the movie is (just) saved from being a total waste of time by star turns from Jean Reno and Hank Azaria, and by some great special effects and action set-pieces. It did manage to hold my interest through all 140 minutes. But with just a little more time spent on the script it could have been so much better.

review_title: did anyone even try to make it interesting?
review_detailed_main:
An old-fashioned gigantic monster flick. The special effects have been updated, too bad the storyline and cinematic cliches haven't.

Surprise, Godzilla's laid eggs. Surprise, one of the eggs is alive. Surprise, Godzilla isn't dead when everyone thinks he is.

Even the special effects aren't so special. The first half of the movie, the computer graphics are so frustratingly obvious. The second half, either they get better, or they look better because it's all in the dark and raining (a la Jurassic Park).

Actually a good 40 minutes of the film is reminiscent of Jurassic Park.

review_title: Awesome Sci-fi take!
review_detailed_main:
I still remember this movie was among my first Hollywood movies to be seen on television. I always like the sci-fi take (here growth in size of organism due to nuclear activity) in these sorts of movies. The other movie that comes this close to the above description when it comes to me is Jurassic Park.

I don't know why it is rated so less.

I rate it a point less only because I disliked the ending otherwise it deserves full marks.

review_title: A film so bad that I figuratively considered suicide.
review_detailed_main:
After seeing what Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich did with Godzilla in 1998, it almost made me lose hope for our species. You would presume, in a Roland Emmerich film, you could at least count on high end visual, but nothing in this film looks or seems remotely real.

I am not a realist who demands that a given sequel, remake, prequel or reboot, must be faithful to source material, I'm not a purist in any sense of the word, Roland and Dean managed to alienate both Godzilla fans of old and new, would-be fans simultaneously. By not adhering to old lore AND replacing it typical Hollywood tropes, they've made a film that has no appeal and zero percent rewatchability.

In the 1990s, this was almost as bad as it got.

review_title: Not As Bad As People Say
review_detailed_main:
Stripped of it's potent essence, thematic meaning, and all of the monster's iconic features, this American Godzilla adaptation fails in every level imaginable despite some obvious nods and references here and there. However, as a monster movie on its own, it gets a little complicated.

Gone are the philosophical dark undertones and social commentary you would expect from a Godzilla movie and are now replaced with silly monster fun and a sense of scale and adventure in the veins of Jurassic Park and Independence Day starring simplistic characters played by competent actors just casually having fun with the roles they are given.

This is a monster movie that could have been a lot better if it didn't have any ties to Godzilla at all for this movie felt more like Rolland Emmerich's thematic sequel follow up to Independence Day. It's goofy and entertaining while boasting impressive cinematography and state of the art effects that is amazing to look at. It's writing and direction may not have been the best for a proper Godzilla adaptation but it sure is the right way for a fun solid entertainment.

review_title: Soulless and worse
Godzilla, 1998
review_detailed_main:
I love this film, it's really fun and inventive! Great way to spend a couple of hours.

I am pretty unhappy with the amount of hate the film gets; it's good! Too much CGI for my tastes generally but because I can remember being a little kid in the cinema watching it I've got a soft spot for it.

Performances are good, casting is good, plot is good, music is good, it's all fine! Watch this film! And enjoy it!

review_title: better than given credit
review_detailed_main:
Okay, first off Godzilla films, the original and all the remakes, are not very good movies. generally boring, little entertainment and a bit of back story which just doesn't hold up for an hour and a half. Now, I get that the original realized the concept and is a classic; but honestly were you entertained or bored for most of the movie?

This movie on the other hand "is" entertaining. Now, it's not a serious action movie, that's probably the reason for all the negative responses. That and the fact that it was Americanized. I guess the fans were not pleased by that.

This is as much comedy as it is action. It actually makes fun of all the previous Godzilla movies and in my opinion it does a decent job.

It has a certain sense of humor and to enjoy it you've got to like similar films such as independence day. I really liked that movie, so I like this one also. With lines such as "mayor Ebert" with the guy who looks like Roger Ebert, it's just too much fun.

Back in the 90's, we had many original good films; so this was weak in comparison. It almost copies films such as independence day or Jurassic park. Two decades later with so many bad films being made this actually looks like a strong film. In my opinion, it's much more entertaining compared to the original 1954 film, and I give it higher points just for that.

There's a limit to how much an original film with boring plot, bad effects can hold up after 60 years.

6.5 out of 10

review_title: Not true to Science Fiction fans. Jurassic RIPOFF
Leave Godzilla to the Japanese
review_detailed_main:
Being a fan of the big green monster I was excited when this movie came out. What could be better than a new Godzilla flick, in English, fancy graphics and set in my home city? Everything. I'd rather watch the old 70's Godzilla cartoon than this, at least that was slightly funny.

This movie made me wish I was blind and deaf. I gained a greater love and appreciation for a cheesy green suit with a man inside of it. I never knew I would miss that so much. This movie proves one thing: Better graphics doesn't make a better movie.

I honestly regret seeing this, and add it to the top of my "Movies that should not have been made" list.

review_title: Decent Special Effects but little else works
Another good and well made Godzilla movie 6/10
review_detailed_main: As much as I'm surprised from how good the movie turned out to be, I got to admit it was really fun and enjoyable. The visual effects were good and better than I thought they would be, but they were still old, you can definitely tell the visual effects were from the late 90's and so it looks silly. Not like the visual effects in later years of Godzilla movies: (2014) and (2018). Even the character of Godzilla seemed a little funny and ridiculous. The updated version of him in the newer films looks better. Though I think the plot was more interesting than the plot we had in other of Godzilla's movies. Let's make a comparison: the movies of Godzilla today have a lot of green screen and CGI which is necessary but on the other hand takes control over the film. Which means the movie is left with characters screaming left and right and doing nothing. Now with this version there is CGI and green screen but there is a bigger plot more interesting, with characters who do a lot and a bigger film set. Like it's not only green screen but real film locations. Overall an enjoyable film and it doesn't matter much which film of Godzilla you prefer, they'll likely be the same.

review_title: This is not Godzilla
review_detailed_main:
When i have seen the 2014 film titled Godzilla which i called it as my most favorite films ever when until that the IMAX sign said "100% less Matthew Broderick" which i never known why so i have to check the 1998 film and my thoughts... It's awful, no questions it's just awful with to many reasons:

1. The Godzilla design's is nothing look like the original version and it make me mad that this version was a female, but TOHO themselves said that original Godzilla was a MALE and also mocking 1998 Godzilla known as Zilla.

2. Idiotic characters like Dr. Niko, Audrey and even the US Army.

3. It also parody and mocking at Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel as the Major and Assistant, which i find it offensive for against only critics.

4. This US Army is destroys every building than Zilla.

5. Poorly acting.

6. Both Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich is used to disliked the original Godzilla franchise which it make fans of Godzilla angry.

I'm sorry everyone this movie is give an 1 out of 10.

review_title: It's atomically Ok
review_detailed_main: The movie is generic and cheesy and pretty stupid, but it has a little charm. This is the movie that got me into Godzilla. I can forgive it for its flaws.

review_title: What on Earth were they trying to do with this?
review_detailed_main:
Basically the movie is about a shallow drama between an ambitious and underhanded news reporter and a wimpy scientist, and you end up not giving a damn about either one of them. The fact that Godzilla is trashing New York in the background is given secondary importance, and after knocking down a few buildings he gets caught up in a suspension bridge and stays there anyway.

This movie could easily have gone places, but as it was it's ineptly handled and falls flat on every level. Not nearly as entertaining as an original 70's Godzilla movie. This was simply a merchandizing vehicle, and a rather sad one at that.

Rate 1/10

review_title: Very watchable compared to current releases.
review_detailed_main:
Although it's not a particularly thoughtful or artistic film, no sane person expects it to be. It is a competently made and very watchable monster-disaster film, much more so than the voguish Cloverfield, which has stunningly bad characterisation, and a distinct lack of narrative structure. As a film, Cloverfield is woefully underwritten and the monster looks awkward and derivative of the creature in the excellent Host.

The action sequences in Godzilla are far more intricately choreographed, and the monster is more convincingly rendered, which is saying a lot considering the CGI is ten years older, but then a number of modern CG films seem to trade fidelity for hyper-kinesis, so that everything is moving too fast to make out details, which is just conning the audience; there are very few money shots, like the Brachiosaur in Jurassic Park.

There is a corny aspect, but it is charming, and not hopeless hokum, like 2012, which is probably the worst Emmerich film i've seen, and i've seen 10,000 BC.

Like a lot of films of the mid to late nineties, there is assumption that the audience still have a respect for story, and most nineties films of this genre stand up quite well to the dross like the later Star Wars prequels, Transformers, Skyline and Clash of Titans, which have no sense of writing talent behind them, and the characters are just types.

Even the effects of newer films look poor, due to aforementioned hyper-kinesis/ shaky-cam visuals.

Why is it that most modern event movies are so poor on all fronts?

review_title: Just Horrible
review_detailed_main:
I dont want to waste anymore of my time than I already did watching this move. It is just a horrible movie. Asinine plot, characters, cliche lines "Yes, I said bomb Madison Square Garden", "Try and stop me"

They destroy MSG with only 6 minutes notice - LMAO. Who needs to evacuate the area, warn the folks who live there or stop the Long Island Railroad and NJ TRansit trains entering into Penn Station (MSG sits above Penn Station)? Nah, just bomb it.

Avoid at all costs.

review_title: "What is this? The virgin lizard?" I loved it.
Not exactly Godzilla but still entertaining...
Was it intended to be good or was special effort put into making it look stupid?
review_detailed_main:
I've HAD it with hollywood 'destruction movies'. What's the difference if an American city is being wrecked by a volcano, a tornado, a giant lizard, a meteor, and of course, aliens.... The rest is constant. Bad plot, bad acting, expensive CGI and the fear of a possible upcoming sequel.

I guess some movies are made for theater, and some directly for video. This one was made directly for MST3k. Have fun with it, boys.

review_title: Blech!
review_detailed_main: How is this film not in the bottom hundred? I've only walked out on a movie twice in my life, and this movie was one of those times. It's like they were making it up as they went along: "We killed it, yay! Oh, wait, it's not dead. Ok, now it is. Oh no, it's a she and it just had babies!" And on and on. Awful stuff.

review_title: It knocked me off my feet...
This Film isn't all that bad to be honest
Re-watched, and was as bad as I remembered it
review_detailed_main:
Granted, some movies don't improve with time. This one was made 5 years after Jurassic Park and didn't show an improvement technically, but neither that nor faithfulness to some 60s rubber suited actor effort is what bothers me. And sometimes nostalgia actually makes you forgive and forget. I actually thought it would, and was surprise it didn't.

My problem is that it's so shallow and dull. All of its flaws, technically or otherwise, would have faded if it would allow anyone to be sucked in. But instead, it reminded me of my experience in theaters - basically turning me from fan to non-fan of Reno and Broderick. That takes some effort. I can't think of anyone in the cast that I liked at all. That's pretty bad, and it's the director's fault.

If you ever wanted to see a story that you can predict from the disc cover to the end scene and want to hate everyone in it and be bored by boring scenes, boring lines and boring screenplay while you're at it, this is the one.

It is terrible. I mean it's a movie, it has some form of story, actors say lines, but it's just completely pointless to watch.

review_title: not as bad as everybody says it is
review_detailed_main: This film is not as bad as everybody says it is. It was an okay way to spend a couple of hours. Look, when I go to a film entitled, "Godzilla", I'm not expecting Shakespeare!! It was slow in spots and the acting stunk, granted, but I defy anyone to say they were bored from the time our heroes entered Madison Square Garden until the end of the picture.

review_title: Can't helicopters go up and down ?
review_detailed_main:
In this sad flick they can't. Seems the RE/DD team just retooled ID and stuck a lizard in it instead of actually watching a previous Godzilla movie. Where's Godzilla's personality? Give me a guy in a rubber suit any day over this tripe.

Bueller?? Bueller??

review_title: An okay movie on its own, but not as a Godzilla movie
review_detailed_main:
This is not bad. The acting is cheesy but in a good way, the action scenes are somewhat exciting, and the effects are decent. It's an okay movie. Nothing groundbreaking, but still watchable.

But that's only when you think of it as its own thing. If you think of it as a Godzilla movie, it's a horrible adaptation. Godzilla looks and acts nothing like any previous version of Godzilla, to the point of being unrecognizable. Also the Baby Godzillas feel like a Jurassic Park rip off.

Overall, it's a decent enough movie in its own, just forget that this is supposed to be Godzilla.

review_title: OK, but too Hollywood
review_detailed_main: First of all, I don't consider this a Godzilla movie at all. No wonder Godzilla-fans call this Godzilla "GINO" ("Godzilla In Name Only"). This is because the Godzilla here doesn't look like the real Godzilla at all, but more like a Tyrannosaurus Rex. I just don't get why Hollywood so often have to make own versions that tend to be worse than the originals. Anyway, if you forget all the Godzilla-stuff, then this is an OK disaster movie. Taking place mostly in Manhattan, New York, I guess everyone can figure out what happens. The movie is entertaining and has some good special effects, but I think they should have ended it much earlier. The last 20-25 minutes was really too much, as it had been more than enough action in the movie before that.

review_title: Not Bad!
review_detailed_main: Godzilla is a better film than I had expected. I brought this film for a cheap price because I wanted to see if this film was entertaining. It was for the most part. This film revolves around a giant monster the size of a dinosaur destroying New York City and having many babies. I think that the plot was pretty good. Some things don't make sense, but this film is just meant for fun. The acting is a little shabby and weak. Matthew Broderick and Jean Reno are fine. Maria Pitillo does need some acting lessons. The soundtrack is great especially the end credits music. The technical stuff for Godzilla was great. The special effects are decent. This film can be scary to little kids. I rate this film a 8/10.

review_title: Enjoyable
review_detailed_main:
This is an enjoyable popcorn movie... just as all other Roland Emmerich (who according to me is "The people's director" to prove my point note that Emmerich won Audience award for the best director at the European film awards) Yes it is highly commercial. The graphics are good. The special effects may be the best ones that year. The movie is not too violent - makes it ideal for all ages. I has got laughs. The music is good too. Not judging it - but the movie is not for those who want to find some meaning. It is pure entertainment. It's called sci-fi but its only fiction not science. People go watch it. Its good entertainment.There is also a bit of politics. Emmerich was very careful not to stress on the nuclear tests as it could lead to unwanted attention on the sub-plots.

Ted Elliott(story) & Terry Rossio (story) and Dean Devlin (story) & RolandEmmerich (story) Dean Devlin (screenplay) & Roland Emmerich (screenplay seem to hold to the Shakespeare method of making subplots for realism instead of Aristotlian principle of here and now. But they are careful not to get too much into the subplots to take away the electricity - good job! The acting was bad (flat). David Arnold won the BMI film music award for his music as he deserved. David Bloch and April Webster did a bad job finding the crew. The sound effects were good then again all technical aspects of the film were good. Over all it is a good movie. Watch it Watch it Watch it Watch it Watch it ........

review_title: a disaster movie becomes a disaster of a movie
review_detailed_main: If they had played this serious, you could have had a decent movie. Instead the producers and directors were so intent on having so many inside jokes and "bon mots" that the story is just lost. Also, having so many comedic actors was distracting. Matthew Broderick? Harry Shearer? Hank Azaria? More suited to light comedy fare. Not a disaster movie. Which ended up making this a disaster of a movie. And what was with all the rain? I felt drenched after watching this. I hope that someone somewhere decides to update godzilla, and do it the way it should have been done this time. With a sense of responsibility, and without putting in silly grudges. And with some decent acting. A nice script. God...the list goes on and on...

review_title: So bad that it took the God out of Godzilla
review_detailed_main:
With the new Godzilla film being released in cinemas now, I couldn't help but think back to this 90's version of Godzilla. A film so poor that it is often called Zilla because people do not consider this film to be deserving of the name. But what made this film so bad? Well, everything. From the weak writing to the poor CGI there was nothing that made this film worth watching.

But the bigger question is, how do you screw up such an easy premise? The concept of Godzilla is easy, a monster who causes havoc and destroys cities, often choosing to fight other monsters also. In this film however, the destruction that Zilla causes is minimal at best, as more damage is done to the city by the army. And this is probably the main reason people hate this film. If you can't understand the basic concept that the monster is supposed to destroy the city then don't make a monster movie.

You can also go at great lengths talking about why none of the characters work at all. Broderick being bland and generic. Mario Pitillo being weak love interest who we never see any reason as to why the pair were interested in one another. And then there is the dreadful Siskel and Ebert parody which was a very weak poke at two of the greatest critics just for putting down Emmerich's films (which Ebert actually commented on stating that if Emmerich was trying to put them down on film they could at least have them be killed by the monster). But far more than anything else in this film we again think of how they screwed up the monster. He is a bland monster who lacks any character whatsoever. In the old Godzilla films the monster did have a personality with various fighting and death scenes having an emotional impact. The only way this one can have an impact is how we feel about it killing are beloved real Godzilla from the classic movies.

Then there's the action itself. The destruction that Godzilla does cause is often off-screen with the film only showing us the aftermath such as badly designed destroyed building. Then when it does get to showing us the action (in those rare scenes) the effects are weak. In contrast to a film like Jurassic Park which came 5 years earlier using ground breaking special effects and making us believe those dinosaurs are there, Godzilla seems to do the opposite and do everything possible to show that it wasn't there. It would be difficult for anyone to believe that he wasn't computer rendered for a single frame with a weak design and incredibly unnatural movements.

The worst crime this film commits is that it lacks a single moment to make this film worthwhile. It had no good action sequences. It lacked any funny moments. And it failed to create the monster Godzilla instead creating a bland generic monster who seemed to be coming off from the Jurassic Park hype, trying to rip of the film in every way possible with its monster. I can only hope that when I see Godzilla (2014) next week it's a better film than this and at least bares some resemblance to the character of Godzilla.

review_title: Time To Revisit This Monster Mash
Dont look at it as a Godzilla film
review_detailed_main: I've seen so much hate for this movie just because it's called Godzilla. If you take that name away and look at as it's own monster movie, then it's a pretty enjoyable popcorn monster flick. The acting can be cheesy at times, or just not up to par, but the action sets are fun and the effects are fairly decent given its age. I'm a massive Godzilla fan so I can understand the hate this movie has. But if you can block out that association then you have a fun creature feature that could have been more accepted if they didn't tack on the Godzilla name

review_title: Big Lizard makes babies and they all meet Ferris Bueller
review_detailed_main:
So it's Friday night & I'm going through the DVD collection and a found this wonderful little gem of a film that I've never seen before. All I can say is thank goodness for the scan button on the remote. I've never seen money wasted so much as in this 2+ hour piece of s***! Fast forward to the end, those last few seconds, I've never laughed so hard in my life. I still don't know how this DVD got in my collection but it's going out with the trash in the morning.

Can someone tell me where I can be reimbursed? I hate to fill our landfills with even more trash.

I think...

peace ya'll GODZILLA

review_title: What did you expect??
review_detailed_main:
Watch some of the old Godzilla movies! If it werent for Godzilla being such a cool monster, they are pretty lame - plot wise!

This Godzilla is no different! Well actually, this is a different monster - A cool monster, but not the old Godzilla!

This Godzilla is a whole lot more watchable than the old movies... Get rid of the Raptors from Jurassic Park tho!

I enjoyed Godzilla 98 trashing New York and in particular the building that I work in!! (maybe thats why i like the movie!)

For those who say the cab scene is unbelievable - its a dinosaur rampaging through Manhattan!!!!! That in itself is unbelievable!

I give it a 7 out of 10

review_title: Brave try???
review_detailed_main: This film starts out with a great deal of promise, but soon degenerates into a display of the efforts of the special effects department to dazzle the viewer. Unfortunately the story line somehow gets lost in all of this. A major glitch occurs when the creature, Godzilla, has attacked New York but disappears, only to be found underground when Matthew Broderick opens a man hole cover. A creature of this size can burrow underground without leaving a trace? NO WAY. The creature then pops out and once more terrorizes the city. The city is supposed to go through an evacuation, but, if this happens, it is cleverly concealed, since it remains populated with myriads of people. The creature supposedly lays a few zillion eggs, requiring massive efforts to destroy them, apparently successful until the ending. I wonder how Matthew Broderick managed to get himself trapped into this turkey. He was excellent in Torch Song Trilogy, The Freshman and Glory, but this was a real mistake for him. I think he needs to fire his agent and get a better one.

review_title: Not as bad as they say!
A complete waste of celluloid
Honestly this is the best Godzilla movie
review_detailed_main: Rolland Emerich made the hardest movie ever and probably one of the greatest director of all time. Each actor were perfect in their role. I miss these actor especially the curly blonde hair she was so adorable. I wish I could see her again in similar roles her facial expressions were so intuitive great actress.

review_title: You had to grow up with it
review_detailed_main:
Is this movie bad? I suppose so...

I still love it! And nothing will ever change that.

Godzilla was created by Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich, the same team behind Independence Day. There is no better way to describe what this film turned out to be. It's Independence Day with a giant Iguana, instead of aliens.

As a lifelong Godzilla fan, I do have to agree that this is Godzilla in name only. But how does it stand on it's own merits.

The tone and direction is exactly the same as Emmerich's other films. Fun action, amazing special effects, cardboard characters, wooden performances, and cliché filled scripts. Matthew Broderick is amusing to watch in the film, he seems to be trying to do the "awkward nerd" routine, but it just comes off as rather awkward in general.

Jean Reno is fantastic. I maintain that there is no movie this man could not save. He does all he can with this performance, giving us mystery, a commanding presence, and some of the films genuinely funny moments.

The design of Godzilla (or Zilla as he is now known) is very strange. At the time this was somewhat of a disappointment after all of the marketing. We we're expecting Godilla, and we got a ugly looking Iguana. They really, truly did take the "God" out of Godzilla here. The effects are cool though, even for a nineties movie.

So why do I love this movie? It's a fun movie, and it doesn't need to be anything more then that. The 2014 Godzilla and Pacific Rim became the new standard for American monster films, but this one came long before, it failed. But it's still fun...

Granted I was 7 years old, that could be a factor I suppose. Is the movie good? Nope, not really. Would it work for a modern audience? I doubt it. Did 7 year old's in the late nineties like it? Good god I hope so!

If you found this review rather boring, you most likely would not like the film.

review_title: Very disappointing
review_detailed_main:
I was gutted after watching this, as I expected something excellent after the hype before it's release. I went to see it on it's opening weekend and switched off quarter the way through. The special effects were good for 1998 but it was boring. The characters were dull and it was too predictable.

I don't recommend at all.

review_title: Actually makes you dumber
Very middling Godzilla movie by famed average of budgets Ronald Emmerich
Don't See It More Than Once - Trust Me.
review_detailed_main:
I really enjoyed "Godzilla" when I went to see it at the movies about 2 years ago, but now it starts to seem like trash and tosh in one bit.

"Godzilla" has alot of un-needed violence, the effects are erm - looking kind of fake here and if they think Maria Pitillo is sexy - think again. Sorry guys - I have, too, come to the conclusion that "Godzilla" is pretty stupid.

My rating : 6 and a half/10.

review_title: but seriously....
review_detailed_main:
Ok, for those who have NOT seen it: Freak lizard is created because of radioactive leakage on its tropical island. It grows up and heads to New York and terrorizes the place. Uh oh, it lays eggs (it's a-sexual!) in madison square garden. Submarines chase Godzilla down in the East river (or wherever it was) and blast it with missiles. It dies but we're not sure. Then eggs hatch (200 of them) with Ferris, his pretty ex-fiancée, Hank Azaria, and french hero guy in the Garden. But godzillies get blown up without Ferris and everyone else dying. Ferris kisses the girl. But soft, Godzilla lives, and he's pissed. But Ferris and friends out-race it and lure it to the Brooklyn bridge. It gets blasted with missiles on the bridge when it gets tangled in the support wires. It dies, heroic cheers ensue, the end...But soft! A baby godzilla egg survived the blast! Part 2 look out!

Now you don't need to watch it. Don't worry, you didn't miss anything.

ok, now for the comment: this flick annoyed the hell out of me. Here's why:

-about half-an-hour is wasted to show people with wide eyes and dropped jaws, frozen stiff every time they see the thing. I realize people probably would indeed be frozen with fear, but for the movie and our sake, RUN! We don't need to see them stare every single time.

-it took an hour before we saw the damn thing's face.

-for God's sake, helicopters can fly vertically.

-cliche, cliche, cliche. It's only an action/fantasy movie, but for crap's sake, they could have used different methods in presenting this movie to us. eg, different lines, camera angles, methods of keeping us in suspense. I was rolling my eyes in the first minute of the movie.

-basically, it's been done before, only Speilberg actually presented a movie with newer methods of suspense, and too many films after it have ripped him off, this one was the last straw.

I actually yelled in the middle of the movie, out of anger, because I was so ****ed off. Every line, every scene, every camera angle, every character, was played. The effects are fine but they were done 4 years ago. I have a feeling that this movie was meant to be a cult classic. You know, bad but yet people love it. Well, I hated it. After careful consideration, I've determined that it's my most hated film. Well, at least it affected me. Movies are supposed to do that.

review_title: Godzilliant!!!
review_detailed_main:
Ladies & gentlemen, let me introduce myself as one, unique, warped individual. In what sense? Am I the only person on this planet that enjoyed this eye-fest of a flick? If you went into this movie expecting a high brow, thought provoking, deeply characterised, emotion-stirring movie then of course you are going to be disappointed. What Godzilla is though, is a thoroughly enjoyable special-effects laden romp. Yes, the acting is a bit ropey in places. Yes, it relies heavily on special effects. Yes, the characterisation is a bit shallow. But so what! Did you enjoy it? My answer is an emphatic YES!!! Grab a tub of popcorn, dim the lights, turn the surround sound up and marvel as Madison Square Gardens see more action than it has done for many years.

A definite 7 outta 10

review_title: Not really great
review_detailed_main:
It's interesting that another re-make is coming out this year. Man, time flies because I vividly remember when this movie came out and the excitement it caused.

I thought when the movie came out it would be good because of the filmmakers.

Personally, I didn't care for the story. However, being a kid growing up with that series with all its innocence, these wonderful Godzilla cartoons you watched.

Anyway, this is simply OK entertainment. I do not think a sequel will ever be made. This is the problem of not getting it right the first time.

review_title: Fun but they should not use Godzilla or Gojira
review_detailed_main:
Just like the movie "Them!" that had an A-bomb in the desert create big ants, this one is the story of an A-bomb set off by the French creating a jumbo lizard.

You know or can guess the story. The attraction for this movie is the new actors and ability to make new spooky situations as Dr. Niko Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick) the worm doctor teams up with Philippe Roaché (Jean Reno) the insurance agent, and Audrey Timmonds (Maria Pitillo) the worm doctor's ex-girlfriend, team up to remove the threat before anyone finds out it is there And France was responsible. How are they doing?

One note: I did not know Gojira had a nickname until someone saw him and said "Fire at Will."

Never mind that the Hudson River looks like Falls Lake, Backlot, Universal Studios - 100 Universal City Plaza, Universal City, California, USA.

review_title: Who's worse? Ed Wood or Roland Emmerich?
review_detailed_main: It's hard to say. It's pretty tough to top Ed Wood. However, this has got to be the s**ttiest movie I have ever laid eyes on! It's badly acted and has a dumb plot(Oops, I forgot. There is no plot.). Not to mention the fact that the old Godzilla in a rubber suit has gone to hell to make room for this loser. The only good that came out of making this was that it bombed in theaters. For once, audiences fought back, reminding the idiots that made this thing that people won't stand for s**tty movies, even if they do have special effects. I've seen effects movies that actually have plots. The special effects in this movie serve as junk food for the brains, and are the only saving grace for the entire movie. And even the effects don't please the eye! This movie does injustice to the big fella, as well as audiences who thought they were coming to a good movie. I don't even know why I'm wasting my time writing about this! I guess it's meant to warn you to save your money and your time for something better.

review_title: Are you guys kidding?
review_detailed_main:
Showed this movie to my girlfriend who has never seen any Jurassic Park/Dinosaur movies ever and she couldn't believe this movie was made in 1998. Her unbiased opinion was that she found the movie to be pretty good.

I Appreciate the work that has been put in to make the creatures look so real, the SFX were stunning and the storyline wasn't half bad either. Too bad there wasn't an official sequel to it but a classic in my book, dare I say it better than Jurassic Park? Nevertheless, see this movie regardless of the critics and for your love of dinosaurs. I rate this movie 9/10 on the bases of SFX alone.

review_title: Don't Hate The Monster, Hate The Movie
review_detailed_main:
Hard to believe it's been 16 years since we were force-fed this film! But, on the eve of a new Godzilla thrashing theaters, I felt the urge to see a blast from our G-Fan past. Fortunately, much of the hatred for Zilla '98 has died down (mostly due to anticipation for the upcoming redemption by Hollywood next month).

While I could sit here and write volumes and volumes on 'the bad' of the film, I think it's been done to death. Instead, I'd like to focus on some of the 'good' the film had to offer (yes, there was SOME good to the film). For parents, this movie is what I could call a "safe" G-flick (much like the original Toho films). By this, I mean there's barely a foul word uttered, no graphic violence I can recall, and no "every film's gotta have one" sex scene. I felt it was safe enough for my 8 year old step-daughter to watch (yes, my step-DAUGHTER loves Godzilla! I'll make a Jedi out of her yet!).

The action is over-the-top, well in line for a Godzilla movie. Lots of Godzilla stomping (away from the military), big and loud building explosions (mostly by the military), and absurd amounts of "under-the-line" references to other sci-fi and action films (mostly by the military). There's a lot in Zilla '98 for giant monster fans, action movie fans, and summer "popcorn" movie fans.

As a giant monster movie, Zilla '98 works, and it works rather well. For a Godzilla film, maybe not so much. I myself have accepted it as part of the Godzilla mythology, much in the way as "Halloween-III: Season Of The Witch", or maybe "Friday The 13th Part-V: A new Beginning". It will forever be razzed as a Godzilla film. But, if you look past that, and see it more as a giant monster film, it's not half bad. In the end: don't hate the monster, hate the movie.

review_title: HORRIBLE
review_detailed_main: This movie was a joke!! It was so bad, I don't even know where to begin. My main gripe is with the blond actress, She was awful! I believe she is the worst actress I have ever seen in my life!! Oh gag! That whole sub-plot about her, getting her shining moment on tv, was stupid! I read another comment on here. They said it was a roller coaster ride, Yeah one that makes you wanna throw up.

review_title: Doesn't live up to the trailer- I prefer the original Godzilla (or Reptar)!
review_detailed_main:
When the trailer came out showing the pounding of Godzilla's feet getting louder and then the museum scene getting squished my husband and I cheered. But when the film came to the flicks we heard it stank, so we stayed away.

Godzilla came on TV last night so I decided to watch it. The buzz was true: it didn't live up to the hype or the legend.

The storyline started promisingly, with loads of nuclear blasts and shots of lizards, the Japanese boat getting slashed and sunk, and the old guy screaming Godzilla's Japanese name. But when it switched to Dr. Nick hunting for earthworms and started following him around it quickly turned into another mediocre movie with taglines to tell the audience where the characters were.

The love story with Audury was out of a TV movie. Most of the characters were out of TV movies. The special effects were great: the shots of the planes chasing Godzilla around the canyons of New York skyscrapers were breaktaking.

But poor Godzilla didn't get to do what he does best: knock down buildings, scream, breathe fire and flatten cars, people, and anything that gets in his way. Godzilla mark 1998 is Godzilla lite. He isn't angry, he rips into buildings by accident with his tail, he's too busy looking for fish. The plot with the eggs was as plausible as Dr Nick discovering Godzilla was pregnant with the aid of drugstore Be Sure tests. The idea of Madison Square Garden full of eggs that started to hatch was awesome, and the baby Godzillas fighting over bags of popcorn was cute, but it was a plot from another film.

I was glad when Godzilla came back and started eating the main characters. Why did the writers have to digress with the pregnancy plot? It wasn't the Godzilla everyone knows and loves.

The movie needed to focus more on what makes Godzilla great: wailing and stomping buildings, cars, people. The Rugrats' tribute to him with Reptar was right on target. I wanted more shots of mass destruction that made Tommy gurgle and kick over his blocks with joy. I wanted to feel that delight in strength and power too.

If this is Godzilla, I prefer Reptar!

review_title: At Times Entertaining and at Other Times Tedious
It's big, it's scary, it's loud it's Godzilla!
review_detailed_main:
Yep, Hollywood did it again. They took yet another Japanese star and turn it into a movie, this time under the direction of Roland Emmerich. Now I will never, ever deny that I enjoy this film, I really do. I always wanted it in my collection, I was amazed by the trailer and I was blown away by the film but in all that shock and awe alas the movie is one large, noisy turd as most of the Emmerich films. But, I got to admit, Emmerich can make some highly entertaining turd films. And I think this is one of my favorite of all Emmerich films ever I still have it in my DVD collection.

Now, if you have watched the original Gojira (1954), then you realize that you are expecting a totally different story. First the movie opens with atomic bomb footage, in French Polynesia, something big emerged from the depths and attacked a Japanese fishing ship. Yep, that's one of those "slap in the face" scenes, where the writer, or director wants to say to the original Japanese film – our monster is better! Well talking about ego. And after that, another accident occurred, this time with US fishing boats. Now that's entirely different from Japanese movies. In their movies we saw Godzilla fights numerous monsters, aliens and even King Kong but the Americans are the one who increased the plot with the Godzilla's plans to make a nest in New York where else? But, the idea of nesting? Hmmm well, I guess that we needed a new idea for a big lizard. And it's not male, or female, it breeds asexual. Although I thought that there are two big lizards, but fortunately I was wrong, and good thing I was wrong. So, the story is simply American in a simple American way. It's bearable.

Time for actors: Matthew Broderick as Dr. Tatopoulos. Matthew was definitively very well payed for this film, so he looked all the time without any emotions, he was just staring at people and stuff and a big lizard and talk in his usual youngster voice and the guy never seems to get old. But, what I like about his performance that he constantly looked funny, especially in Madison Square Garden scenes, he entertained me pretty enough. Jean Reno plays Philippe Roache the French intelligence agent who came to "clean up his sh*t". What do I mean by that? Now this is not a big spoiler the French atomic testing were done by French people and that's why Roache (his last name was there to make ridicule of him) is here. Reno was good, in his own French guy in US element. He was the badass of the film. We have Maria Pitillo as Audrey Timmonds, a former girlfriend of Nick's. Pitillo was so funny, so bad in her performance, no wonder you didn't saw her anywhere else in other films, this film remains the best known in her career. Hank Azaria? Oh, that's not all. Harry Shearer and Nancy Cartwright are also in the film. Moe the Bartender , Mr. Burns and Bart Simpson are in the film? What was that for? You expect for American audience to recognize them? To recognize their voices? Well, maybe some of them maybe know but that does not helping! Hank and Harry were funny well it was their job to be funny in the film. We also have Kevin Dunn and Doug Savant, they were good but somehow aw f**ck it, they were all funny in their performances, it's like you are watching a film based upon a world where everyone is comedian except Japanese and the monster itself. To also mention Michael Lerner's appearance in the film as Mayor Ebert yep, you are right another slap in the face to the two famous, respected and hated critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert, who obviously didn't like Roland's previous films.

When it comes to the monster design, I won't lie to you I kinda liked it. It was an idea that Godzilla mutated from ordinary Iguana, but when you look at it, It doesn't even look nearly as Iguana. This Godzilla is more lean, to make him more faster and more well built for swimming. So it's not that bad. Overall, this is one large, imposing turd of a film. It's your opinion you like it, or you don't. And I do, because I think that the movie is very entertaining. But I do not include the humor in the film not all the time. I mean the script is just ridiculous, CGI is not bad, it's very good at some scenes, visuals are good, camera work – not bad, I like the underwater scenes, sound effects are brilliant, but I think the best thing is the music score by David Arnold, it's powerful and it presents monster pretty good. So no matter how amused I were it's still that's a lot of turd

And one more thing Hollywood stop touching Japanese things

review_title: Godzilla (1998)
review_detailed_main:
Directed by Roland Emmerich. Starring Matthew Broderick, Maria Pitillo, Jean Reno, Hank Azaria, Kevin Dunn, Michael Lerner, Harry Shearer, Lorry Goldman, Vicki Lewis, Arabella Field, Doug Savant. (PG-13)

Japan's most famous giant lizard gets rebooted and rerouted to NYC, where it climbs out of the sea and tries to catch a Broadway show, then accidentally steps on and knocks over a bunch of stuff, which makes the mayor and military very unhappy. Spectacularly stupid and visually unspectacular, this monstrosity is the very definition of a tentpole-wannabe; even on the level of effects-driven "popcorn entertainment," it's never wise to insult the intelligence of the audience this badly. Broderick isn't exactly a prime candidate for action-junk leading man, but it's hapless Pitillo that could really use a good reptile-on-a-rampage squashing (at least Reno emerges unscathed, as expected). For anyone afraid that it might get monotonous watching ol' Gojira stomp around a city for over two hours, rest assured that there's an extended bit involving its newly-hatched babies scurrying about and looking for human-flavored snacks that shamelessly rips off the "Jurassic Park" raptor scenes. Makes Emmerich's last picture, "Independence Day," astonishingly watchable by comparison. Plus, the soundtrack desecrates Led Zeppelin's "Kashmir," so there isn't even a respite when the credits start to roll.

24/100

review_title: Not Godzilla
review_detailed_main:
First of all, this is not a Godzilla movie. It does fairly well as a monster movie except for the god awful choice of Maria Pitillo as the lead actress. She makes dumb blonds seem like Einstein. There are plenty of really smart blonds out there but Pitillo is just plain embarrassing. The computer graphics are outstanding. I would have rather seen someone like Peter Weller as Dr. Tatopoulos. Why they kept making a joke out of his name is beyond me and the total disrespect shown him is uncalled for. This man is a scientist of some esteem. How he ever had Pitillo as a romantic interest with his genius and her crass stupidity is a true mismatch. Jean Reno is very good as he is, in my opinion, all of his roles. Vicki Lewis, who I think is sexy as hell, as Dr. Elsie Chapman, also did well in her role considering the script. Hank Aaria as 'Animal' and Arabella Field, another cutie, did quit well with their parts. Kevin Dunn as Colonel Hicks was a disgrace to our officer corps. When Broderick corrected Hicks' mispronunciaton of his name, Tatopouolos, Hicks answered with a 'whatever',,,disgusting! What's the story with Sergeant O'Neil? He is not funny, just plain sickening. He is as dumb as a brick and a disgrace to every non-com in our military.

The opening scene with the fishing vessel in natural and 'unnatural' distress is impressive. I was nine years old when the original 'Godzilla' was released and it scared the bejeesus out of me. I now have fifteen follow-up 'Godzilla' films in my collection and love each one. These are tongue-in-cheek matinée gems. I am a physician and when I want to escape from reality, and 'Godzilla' movies are a real escape from reality, I pop one in the VCR/DVD player.

For crying out load, one has to understand that this new version is still a reality escape but with tons of acting flaws with weak scripting which I can love in B films like 'The Monster that Challenged the World' but are inexcusable in a costly film like the one under discussion. With all of the actors and actresses out there that would probably jump at chance to play(and have fun)in a really good write of this film, I can see why they did not jump. If they had a really good screenplay script and the actors were anywhere near believable this could have been a really good film. They missed a real opportunity here, an opportunity wasted,,a chance to introduce 'Gozilla' to an entirely new generation of kids and adults that are kids at heart,,not to mention the opportunity for at least one sequel. Where was the Morgan Freeman narration, Will Smith's excitement or even Elvira's campiness.

Sad. When I left the opening day showing at the local cineplex, I was almost in tears. No fire breathing, no empathy for the big 'G', ...what it could/should have been and is not...so sad :(

review_title: The Horror...
review_detailed_main: What an agonizing task it was to sit through this mezmerizingly banal opus to the brain dead. A child with Forrest Gump's IQ would be insulted by this charmless embarassement. Please stop the makers of this film before they make another picture.

review_title: I find myself watching it every time it comes on..
Let's just pretend it didn't happen....
review_detailed_main:
First we see some nuking. Then some idiotic pseudo-science babble. Ships get attacked. Some old wino fisherman gets chased from a pier by a tidal wave - is this going to end any time soon? Then the big lizard shows up - it's Godz-! Oops! No, it'snot. It's got some weird birth-defect jaw. It doesn't lumber around and squash things. It doesn't breath fire. It wouldn't stand up to an attack by any space monster. Then there's more pseudo-science babble, and then the army shoot at it, and then it disappears - and that music - will it never end? And who are these jack-*ss reporters anyway? And who the heck is the blonde, where'd she come from? Then there's the french guy, don't know why he's here either, I thought this was the "American" version - Underwater sub attack; in the middle of New York. Why am I having a hard time believing this? Should have rented "Godzilla: Giant Monsters All-Out Attack" again, now that film has truly awesome special effects. This is "American version" is all dippy "CGI 101" stuff.

Now there's hundreds of them. And they chase people around and eat 'em up - good! Rotten actors anyway.

More cheesy special fx, and blowing things up. Then a car chase - every Hollywood film has to have a car chase, they can't think of any other way to make a "motion" picture? Cheap despite it's millions spent, cynical, stupid, manipulative, and predictable as hell. I spent money to see this? Give it back!

review_title: A fantastic movie...
A fun but frightening American Godzilla
review_detailed_main:
This is kinda a fun film! It really is! Matthew Broderick played in it and many other actors and actresses. Godzilla wasn't a large walking puppet in the eastAsiabut a computer roaming the westUSA. It was rather scary! A little like Jurassic Park but not really.

We saw this at the theater and had lots of laughs and fun. But we got pretty scared too! It wasn't exactly a light film but kinda dark instead. Literality, it was often night and it rained, rained and rained in the film. And that made Godzilla just as scary. I think you should see it, people, if you want fun thrills and chills from an American Godzilla.

review_title: An enjoyable movie, but as had been said a billion times before, it's not Godzilla
The hype was as big as the monster to start with!
review_detailed_main:
It felt like this take on Godzilla was advertised for 2 years in advance of the actual release, every time (it seemed) I went to the cinema I was awestruck by little teaser trailers, in fact the one of the old guy fishing and hooking Zilla is a personal favourite...SIZE DOES MATTER! Love it I do. Sadly as most of us now know, the film didn't meet fans and critics expectations at all, but was the film done down by the hype and an expectation of a masterpiece for the genre?.

Well it didn't help that is for sure, but taking aside that problem, the film only glimpses at what might have been. It has many great points that seem to have been forgotten, so sadly we are all too aware of the film's failings on the makers behalf. The build up in the film is excellent, the makers mount the tension in steady strokes, doing what all classic monster movie makers do, they have you waiting with gripping expectation of the creature by a series of scenarios and inventive dialogue. The sound is incredible, making it an essential viewing for those who cherish home surround cinema, while some of the shots and destruction of New York are well worth the viewers time.

But then? Well they throw the good work away by turning the film's focus away from the big lizard to a story line that was only fitting for the cartoon version of Godzooki. Thus rendering the film as a poor man's Jurassic Park, which quite frankly doesn't sit well. Matthew Broderick, Jean Reno and Hank Azaria all deserved better scripting, hell we all did!

It's not the evil stinker some would have you believe, it does have its moments of both good and bad, it is, by definition, very much a film split down the middle. 5/10

review_title: Watch it for the nostalgia factor
Tacky at times but overall suspenseful
review_detailed_main: Sure there are some campy moments especially during the first hour, but stick with it! It's actually a decent movie and really delivers with the suspense. I felt that the chase scenes were great, I was on the edge of my seat. The tackiness was forgiven by the end of the movie.

review_title: And they call this entertainment.
review_detailed_main:
This movie sucks! I mean it does! What ever happened to Japanese Godzilla. This new Godzilla is so ugly and doesn't look like anything except a hideously disfigured lizard that looks like something designed by H.R. Giger more than Eiji Tsuburaya. This is so awful, I would take fifty Megalons over this. What were they thinking when they made this bomb.

For years I had been excited about this Godzilla movie that was going to be released in 1998. But when I finally saw it, I was appalled! Do you here me appalled! Good night!

review_title: Not as bad as some people say.
review_detailed_main:
