Worse than "Hercules in New York." Should I go on? I still have two more lines to fill...worse than "Surf Nazis Must Die." Worse than "Kung Pow:Enter the Fist." OK...OK...I've filled up 10 lines. I'll stop.

review_title: Better than Armageddon
review_detailed_main: I can't understand why people are rating this lower than Armageddon. I suppose it would had done better if Ben Affleck had starred in it. This film is strictly a popcorn disaster film. Much like the movie version of Batman. The titled character makes too few appearances for my tastes, but the story is still entertaining. It took me a second viewing to get past that "this is not the Godzilla I remember" feeling, but after I did that I found the movie much more enjoyable.

review_title: Has nothing to do with Godzilla, just the title
review_detailed_main: Has nothing to do with Godzilla, just the title. And the new movie comes, and people are saying this the best Godzilla. Is that a joke? Im laughing about that. It is not a bad movie, but this is not Godzilla, not the Godzilla storlyine, and has nothing to do with the orginal Godzilla.

review_title: Not as bad as everybody complains about..
review_detailed_main:
This movie is not as bad as most people say. In fact, it's rating is

highly mis-skewed to other movies much, much, worse.

The special effects are entertaining and the movie is enjoyable.

Of course the plot is not original, there are a bazillion Godzilla

movies. It is certainly better than any of the 'original' Godzillas I

have ever seen. The tiny Godzilla babies, however, are a rip off of

the raptors in Jurassic Park.

The soundtrack is exceptionally good. This has been the only other

movie (asides from The Matrix) that has impressed me with its

soundtrack during the movie.

You should see the movie. 7/10

review_title: awful, apocalypse of filmmaking
review_detailed_main:
It's both a bad and bad made movie. (And I don't mean bad in a good way) The only credits go to the special effects. The story is weak and exploited from earlier made Godzilla- and Dinosaurmovies. The actors are B-grade, but their acting is C-grade (in the acception of Matthew Broderick and Jean Reno) The good scenes are stolen. The script is bad, the dialogues suck. Yuch, both a waste of my time and my money. I never want to see a Roland Emmerich movie ever again!!

PS

It's absolutely uncomprehensible to me that this movie cost $30,= per dvd and a wonderful film as Red River only $8,=!It's an insult, but who cares? I know which movie I'm gonna buy!

review_title: One of my favorite movies =]
A hit and miss affair
review_detailed_main:
Being a Godzilla fan for many years you can imagine my excitement when the museum trailer burst on to screen showing Godzilla's foot! Finally my favourite movie monster was getting the BIG budget re-make it so deserved, coupled with my favourite movie makes Devlin and Emmerich it seemed as if the film was going to be taylor made just for me! After the months of hype and grabbing every scrap of info i could find to try to get the plot, Zilla's final look, and inside gossip, i bought my ticket and grasped it tightly as i was so wound up to see this movie and could only imagine what modern technology would do for my beloved monster.

After 2+ hours of movie and coming back down to reality, i could not help but remain a little confused as to what i just saw? It sounded like Godzilla, the plot was a typical Godzilla plot, even both versions of his name were mentioned, but try as i might, i have to admit, it just didn't FEEL like Godzilla.

If your just looking for a big monster mash up with some tongue in cheek humour, then this is for you. If its the essence and spirit of Godzilla then you might feel like me. Its a good movie but it promised so much, i suppose it was unrealistic to expect a movie with this kind of material to deliver the 'total package' that was in ID4.

review_title: Emmerich's dumpster fire still smolders decades later.
review_detailed_main: After revisiting this film for the first time in over two decades, I was genuinely impressed by the fact that it somehow seemed even worse to me now than it did upon its release. The plot, while unremarkable, is not helped by ridiculously bad dialogue and horrendous performances by the actors (particularly Matthew Broderick, who shows us once again that he is entirely incapable of acting beyond a grade-school play level). Do yourself a favor and skip this horrific debacle.

review_title: The worst movie I have seen in my entire life
review_detailed_main: This movie not only sucked but it had to rip off ideas from 5-6 other movies. There was no real plot, the special fx had holes in it, the acting was terrible and a whole lot more. I went to see this the first day it came out and you know what was funny? I never seen so many people in the theater take so many trips to the bathroom! People didn't want to see the movie, they wanted the movie to end!

review_title: People take this far too seriously...
A good movie, but not a good Godzilla movie.
Most disappointing film experience I've ever had (well, almost)
review_detailed_main:
I bought into the hype when this came out in 1998. I was younger then and went to go see it opening day with my friend. He loved it, but the entire time I saw there awestruck thinking to myself, "Wow, this is actually BORING!" It's not that the film is just stupid. All blockbusters are, after all. It's that Roland Emmerich is so inept here at delivering any sort of entertainment value -- the film takes itself way too seriously for a summer popcorn flick, trying to insert depth and dialogue - both backfire miserably.

Matthew Broderick is sorely miscast as the lead hero and Jean Reno has perhaps the only good role in the entire film.

The CGI sequences are alright I suppose but compared to today's effects, they're outdated -- and when a film relies entirely on effects to wow over its audience, you know it's in trouble.

The end of the film turns into "Jurassic Park" with little Godzillas running around chasing people like Raptors.

This movie is too long, too stupid, too pretentious and too boring.

review_title: Fares better when viewed on TV
review_detailed_main: I just sat through Godzilla '98 at home in widescreen format. I had seen with my family when it opened, and frankly we were very disappointed. My feelings then were: the film was murky, anytime the creature made an appearance it was dark, or raining, or very grey. There was never a ray of sunshine. I felt this is what may have turned people off about it. In the theater it was very hard to follow because of the lack of color. I was also distracted by the sound, it did not enhance the movie for us one bit. My wife and kids felt pretty much the same way. But now nearly 2 years later, I picked up a widescreen videotape, and to my surprise, it was much easier to sit through on a smaller scale. I was able to control the sound so that distraction was easily remedied. The film itself seems so much more entertaining as TV fare, then it did on the big screen. What little color there was to the film seemed to stand out better on the TV, probably because everything was condensed. Although this updating of a classic is not one for the books, it does seem to stand up when viewed on a smaller scale. I think people who saw it in 98 should find a tape and view it again, but, remember to put aside your thoughts about the old Godzilla,and enjoy for what it is-a 2 hour time waster. One more thing, try to get a widescreen version, it does help.

review_title: So Many Special Effects, So Little Story
review_detailed_main: I wanted to like this. I was told by one of my students that a big buck remake of Godzilla was coming out. Then, like happens too often, the big bucks were spent on eye candy and not on a really engaging film. While the lizard was certainly amazing, the way he jumps around and squashes things is almost too formidable. Had he been bent on total destruction there would have been a total annihilation of New York in a few minutes. Of course, his motivations lie elsewhere. He certainly is better than a guy in a Godzilla suit, but eventually get to the humans. I'm not quite sure what to think of Matthew Broderick. He is one of the most bland people I have every seen. Even on Letterman he comes off as the dull guy next door. He also still looks like he's about sixteen. Instead of building really great suspense and waiting for the lizard to make its movie, we have these scientific ramblings. There is humor injected here and there. The newspaper people are ridiculous. The French guys are so out of place that all they do is confuse everyone. Just because you are French, doesn't mean you are stupid. It is a Western country and the people know what's going on in the world. French Roast coffee, indeed! A lame excuse for an on screen commercial. I tried watching this again and was befallen with the same basic endless boredom. The special effects are nonpareil, but after a while they only get you to first base.

review_title: The late 90s
review_detailed_main: I watched this again after 20 years. It took me back to a time when America had nothing more to fear than aliens blowing up the empire state building and a nuclear lizard destroying Manhattan. The pay phones really took me back.

review_title: Some special effects... but this is MOVIE review, so 3/10.
review_detailed_main: Oh well. Tour-de-force of special effects, some of which were good (although none were original), but surprisingly, some of which were embarrassingly bad (e.g. the helicopter chases and F-18 jets...). The plot is so thin that it shouldn't even be mentioned. It almost seems like the whole point of this movie was to do some kind of we-can-do-jurassic-park-too technological masturbation. I just don't get it. This movie has already (even with same english title) been done some dozens of times in Japan (and Jurassic Park II wasn't too far from it either), so why bother? It's not like we have run out of ORIGINAL ideas and REAL plots... It takes just a little courage to do something different, so just do it and stop giving us this rubbish, thank you. 3/10.

review_title: A huge-budget remake of the cheesy overseas monster movies.
review_detailed_main: Godzilla had the Lost World Curse. It was so anticipated, that it could never have been the movie we were hoping for. Remember the previews, one entire year early, at Men in Black? The commercials at midnight on New Years Eve? The "Size Does Matter" billboards that appeared anywhere and everywhere when Summer 98 approached? What kind of movie could possibly live up to that hype? The backlash was pretty bad. Just as soon as the movie opened, there were people who were dying to see it, just so they could say 'guess what? Godzilla sucked!' Well, guess what? Godzilla didn't really suck. It wasn't the summer's biggest or best, just like Hollywood hoped, but it was still a decent monster movie. Godzilla wrecked New York City, and that's exactly what I paid my money to see, so I was pretty happy. It seems silly to include a love story, and yes, we do get Matthew Broderick as a scientist trying to re-hook-up with his ex-girlfriend, virtually the same time as he's trying to stop Godzilla. But it never slows the movie down, there's still plenty of Godzilla smashing buildings and stepping on cars and swatting helicopters. It's a good thing Devlin and Emmerich left all that stuff in. The movie ends with a shameless opening for Godzilla 2, although now there's talk of cancelling the sequel because the backlash was so loud. Well, I hope Sony does go ahead with it, because there's definitely room for improvement.

review_title: Decent for its day
review_detailed_main: Will never go down as a classic but for it's time it's a decent watch, picked it up on 4k today and enjoyed watching it again after all these years.

review_title: Huh how strange a movie called Godzilla, that doesn't actually feature the titular monster!
Piece of cinematic crap.
review_detailed_main: First and foremost, any reboot of this Japanese sci fi classic that would even THINK of hiring Matthew Broderick to play the male lead is going to be a rampant disaster. And this pile of junk certainly doesn't fail to fail. I've never seen so much bad acting in a major motion picture in a long, long time, and even a porno movie is more engaging, not to mention the "pay off" at the end! When I saw this overgrown lizard destroy a nuclear submarine because it apparently knew more about nuclear weapons and tactics with it's pea-brained Jurassic brain, I couldn't stop laughing. And when I saw 100's of it's 10' tall babies taking over Madison Square Garden, this piece of horse pucky REALLY got stupid. If you want to waste your time and your money, watch this turkey. If not, STEER CLEAR. If the original Godzilla could watch this monumental garbage, he'd turn over in his grave.

review_title: One exciting action scene in a movie that runs 139 minutes.
special effects are great
review_detailed_main: although not as spectacular as Jurassic or the Lost World, Godzilla provides some great special effects and some fun action sequences. I enjoyed this film as a roller-coaster ride of action, sound, and visuals.

review_title: Why it's called Godzilla:
review_detailed_main:
$$$$$$

People tend to hate this film for its premise rather than it's film-making qualities. If it was called something else however, it would not have made half as much money. The film itself is poor, a definite thumbs down. No drama, no suspense, no thrills. For a monster film it kind of falls flat on it's face.

It's real crime is that it's called Godzilla. The creature itself has so many differences to the original that it's not right to call it that (Gojira was over 400 feet tall and would tower over the world trade centre). So it's not the actual creature, let alone a remake (it has nothing to do with the plot of the original film either). Just plain fail from Emmerich and co. So the only possible reason for calling it Godzilla must have been to cash in on the name. Thanks but no thanks.

review_title: BEST Modern Godzilla, better than 2014
All Crown - No Filling!
review_detailed_main:
I don't mind some Roland Emmerich films. I tend to be more interested though in the ones that don't focus on disasters and monsters. Godzilla has both. It's a big budget sci-fi action film full of so-called spectacle, but at its heart it's terribly empty and lacking in any genuine dramatic content.

There's no sense of mystery nor surprise. Godzilla is rolled out in the first minute of the movie, after which we get this confusing global whip around, where we find characters such as Dr. Niko "Nick" Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick) an NRC scientist, who is in the Ukraine researching the effects of radiation on wildlife. Within a couple of minutes, he's summoned to Tahiti, then Panama, then Jamaica. All I could think was that he must be experiencing a hell of a jet lag. But no, this is the way Emmerich unfurls the little narrative that we get. I don't think it was ever actually confirmed in the movie, but I think we're expected to believe that Godzilla is a mutated marine iguana, who has been affected by French (LOL!) atomic testing (rather than American).

Anyway the big guy finds his way to New York, where unsurprisingly again, he/she (don't ask) causes a hell of a lot of trouble around the Manhattan area and we later find that he/she is capable of giving birth to 200 (what looked to me like) tyrannosaurus rexes. Yep! All of a sudden there are all these dinosaurs running around. Shades of Jurassic Park! The story is just weird, but one can easily see that Emmerich was clearly intent on moving into Steven Spielberg's dinosaur domain under any illogical circumstances.

This movie is all about visual effects, borrowed ideas from better films (especially those from Spielberg) clichéd dialogue, flimsy and formulaic narratives, illogical plot developments, and lack of character depth. Broderick is a nerdy Sam Neill without the required gravitas, but with a ridiculous beret for goodness sake. He has a love interest played by someone by the name of Maria Pitillo, of whom I've never heard anything about, before or since. She's cute but ... ! Jean Reno turns up looking guilty ... for turning up in a movie like this.

Interesting things: 1 Why is it raining in so many scenes? Is rain a Godzilla thing? It gets seriously tiresome. In Blade Runner there was a reason, but Godzilla? 2 Godzilla seems to change in size depending on the circumstances required of a given "action" scene. Is it possible for instance, that the US forces with all their advanced technology are incapable of finding a 120 m creature hiding in the Hudson River? 3 How many times in movies now has Roland Emmerich supervised the destruction of New York? Does he ever get sick of it?

I've given this movie a 3/10. It's not really worth that, but I figure that with a production this big, at least a lot of people got a lot of work out of it and that's got to be surely worth something.

review_title: Entertaining
review_detailed_main: This is a very well made Godzilla film. It's far from the best and it lacks charm but I enjoyed the spectacle. The human story is pretty forgettable, Matthew Broderick actually is a horrible miscast in my opinion and sinks this film a bit rather than carry it. The effects are mostly good, especially for the time. The sets are really awesome in places. The production quality all round is very high. This also has the best sense of scale for a Godzilla so far, he actually looks huge. Shame they changed the design of Godzilla so much and it's just ugly now. I didn't like the whole plot of baby Godzilla, it felt like a bad Jurassic Park movie. At least the city smashing and finale was very exciting making up for the many shortfalls.

review_title: Great looking Godzilla,fantastic effects,but everything was just not used right.
Still makes for a fun and exciting popcorn flick.
The Monster Summer Event of the 90s
review_detailed_main:
A slick, Hollywood-ized version of a beloved Japanese monster, made to sell to a dumb American audience. Roland Emmerich's 1998 Godzilla serves as a specimen of 90s Hollywood excess. Big, loud, and brain dead. But Zilla (the nickname for this reimagined monster) also represents the fun, excitement, and spectacle of the summer blockbuster events of the pre-superhero era. I wouldn't call it smart, or even good, but Godzilla '98 is a great big ball of cheesy entertainment, and I kind of love it.

Godzilla preserves the 1954 original Godzilla's nuclear backstory, but introduces a mostly original story and characters. Chief among the newcomers is Matthew Broderick as a scientist called on to investigate the strange threat from the sea. Also hanging around are Jean Reno, Maria Pitillo, and Hank Azaria. All are enthusiastically up to the task of running with the mountains of special effects thrown around them. Now calling this story original is generous. At best it plays like a cheap rehash of Jurassic Park. At worst, it's just another monster movie. The kind of set-em-up knock-em-down script by machine that requires no thought and little engagement.

And yet, I was engaged by Godzilla. Not by its ideas (of which there are none), but by its spectacle and its eagerness to thrill. What the "all effects, no story" complaints miss is the impact of truly exciting special effects. Godzilla has those. Emmerich and his technicians conjure some real awesome displays of scale, as well as complex CGI that still makes it point. The action scenes are carefully considered. Storyboarded, framed, and shot to be spectacular. It's an approach to action that is closer to that of the masters like Spielberg or Cameron than to the modern hacks who ship action off to the VFX team. There is a degree of showmanship found here that is nowhere to be seen in something like Kong: Skull Island or Pacific Rim: Uprising.

Emmerich, along with Independence Day writer Dean Devlin, thankfully understand their audience (if not the OG Godzilla fans, then at least me). What I want from Godzilla is not heady sociopolitical philosophy. Nor is it half-assed attempts at human drama at the expense of the main show. What I want from Roland Emmerich's Godzilla is a roller coaster ride. A slam-bang fireworks show of hearty monster destruction. And this is what Emmerich has given us. The characters work. They are likable, sturdy human interests among the chaos. The effects work. The monster has a palpable presence onscreen. The action works. It's staged thoughtfully, and it's variety of locations and scenarios keep it from going stale (shout out to the Madison Square Garden section of the film. Running through the labyrinth of a basketball stadium while being chased by mini-Godzillas is one of the more exciting extended sequences of verisimilitude I can remember). All in all, the thing works as intended. It screams summer, popcorn, blockbuster, and all of the other words we associate with fun at the movies. I'm not supposed to like the American Godzilla, but damn-it-all, I do. I like the rainy, steamy New York atmosphere, I like Broderick's nerdy charm, I like the earnestness of its ultimate message, and I like watching a bunch of buildings get blown up real good. So sue me.

75/100

review_title: O.K. movie if you fastforward through all scenes with people
review_detailed_main:
I never though a new godzilla movie could be made with a worse plot then the old japanese classics. The reason this movie sucks and the classics rule is that the oldies were so bad they were good, this movie is so bad its almost unwatchable. Plus why was this godzilla based on some guys iguana and not GODZILLA! I have to admit that even though this Godzilla really isn't Godzilla it is cool watching (Iguanamonster) run around smashing stuff. Just don't pay attention to the plot(Worm Guy!!!) or the acting, or you will cry.

Gojira, Gojira, Gojira!!

review_title: If Harvey Keitel had played the "mutated lizard" he would probably have pleaded with the director Roland Emmerich, "Where's my motivation"?
"The French save the day, and we don't like that".
review_detailed_main:
That's the only reason. The French save the world. That's the only reason almost all people - in USA, I must say - hate this movie.

In despite of the people searching for sci-fi in a movie named "Godzilla", of the fans of the Japanese movies (Heavens!), of all the past times the duo Emmerich-Devlin had ruined a not-bad-but-remake-of-an-old-idea (i.e. almost all their past movies) this one it's not so bad, guys. But that is not the point. It's about the "masterpiece" of Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich.

The aforementioned duo have spent last years delighting us with some remakes and the like of sci-fi films or ideas (Years ago a young jury at a Cinema Festival for the young here in my country voted "Joey" as best movie, while the real jury voted, more accordingly, "My Life as a Dog". If you want to know for sure Emmerich's opinion about his favorite film, pay attention to the Star Wars DVD Trilogy extras(1)).

The first real "success" of the duo was "Stargate", which is nothing but "Flash Gordon" with the Army around. An almost decent movie, not much expensive (by Hollywood standards) and with a script capable of solve the whole crisis in a hurry that would make George Lucas face turn red in envy. We arrive, we discover this Egyptian demigod (Ra!), we killed him and destroy his superior technology and his powerful pyramid-vessel, thanks for everything, next time will stay a bit longer. Pathetic (the TV series is terribly boring. Sorry).

And then came the martians (whatever). And this, my friends, is your idea of a good spectacle. In that time was fun to see the White House blowing up in a zillion fragments, and your sympathetic army saving the entire world by destroying a whole technologically superior civilization (I'm sorry, not too advanced after all; 50 years and they use the same fighters-computers, as we see in the 51 area sequence), I repeat, an entire civilization (as the president reads in the mind of the "martian", remember? They traveled all at once as friends, like the Indians in an old Spanish joke :D) destroyed in 2 days, at time for the 4th of July. You know, here in Europe we laughed deeply at cinemas with the speech of the president. And cheered, too.

And then came this Godzilla flick, which is, I'm sorry again, the best movie this German-americanized-in-more-than-one-way duo has ever made.

I can remember that in that time, France was really doing nuclear tests in Moruroa (or was Mururoa?). This was the perfect starting point. Given the love this two, Devlin & Emmerich, feel for their land of adoption, USA couldn't at all be responsible for the needed nuclear explosion that, traditionally, unleashed the beast, oh, no. Not the only country who has ever used the bomb against civilian targets, making later the role of victims in "The Day After".

"But ¿what the politics have to do with a movie like this?". Since ALL the cinema is politics, everything. And in this very case, the most. This is a film in the "tradition" which gave fame and fortune to Emmerich-Devlin: an old idea modernized, for all audiences (meaning this you can save the dog but not the woman in certain situations, I suppose), a constant rip of classics (it was "Lawrence of Arabia" in Stargate), like the galactic trench run of the helicopters after the lizard in the middle of NY among other "homages" (not to mention "Jurassic Park", another "masterpiece") and with nerd-but-nice scientist and too-much-nice army men (not to forget the real heroes, the french secret service) who save the day and everything.

At this point I want to call your attention to the other duo, with much more artistic sense than the first one, responsible of the script; I mean the Ted Elliot-Terry Rossio tandem, writers of some very good blockbuster movies like "The Mask of Zorro", "Aladdin", "Pirates of the Caribbean - Episode I :D" and others. I bet my neck about the fact that, having in mind what the first team can do, the best ideas in this movie are the second's: the french not only creating the monster (only an animal hungry for fish!) but in the end destroying it (while the army destroys the luckily evacuated city; luckily for the MPAA and the rating of the film), the origin of the name of the creature and the joke about the Americanization of the original name-film, from "Gojira" to "Godzilla", and fortunately, the US army dying as idiots and destroying NY (is a right-wing classic topic to despise the media, so that's another very different thing, more to the likes of Emmerich-Devlin). About the fact that the french agent's names are "Jean-Claude", "Jean Patrick" and "Jean-Philippe", the "bad" news chief is "Caiman" and the "good" cameraman is "Animal", I can't possibly imagine who had the idea.

The real thing is that the French save the world, man. The Army almost destroy New York. That is no good, right?

Like another American hero would say, I have nothing more to say about this. And sorry for my mad engrish.

(1) In Roland Emmerich's own words "My friends in school liked Fassbinder, and I liked Star Wars", or something like that.

review_title: A monstrous mixed bag.
review_detailed_main:
My Take: It's all spectacle, no thrills. The final hour is satisfying though.

Rated PG-13

I have to admit that back when I was a kid, I really loved watching "Godzilla", mainly because I'm a sucker for monster movies, especially dinosaur films. Another reason is that film criticism does not apply to me yet. Now that it applies, I began to see the real colors of "Godzilla", a weak and flawed film the relies too heavily on effects than plot, pacing and interest. The second half is somehow exciting, but it's the overlong and boring first half that's the problem. If you have it on DVD, you can just fast-forward it to the good parts, but trust me, the first half is darn long. So long (and boring) it almost chews up the entire running time of the film.

The problem of "special-effects vs. good story" is not something new to director Roland Emmerich and co-writer/producer Dean Devlin, who made INDEPENDENCE DAY. But ID4 didn't bore me because it was fun as it is, GODZILLA on the other hand spent too much time showing us the giant lizard's feet than forming much action or human characters among them.

Another thing about this film, is that it tries so hard to be another "Jurassic Park", adding, of course, the rampage of the baby Godzillas and an enjoyable final chase scene. interesting thing about the film. Obviously, it's no "Jurassic Park", and even not "The Lost World: Jurassic Park". It is, mainly, a large lizard movie that focuses more in "destroying" New York than giving audiences what they came for.

I'd be lying if a say I didn't enjoy this film. It somewhat takes off on the second half, but getting there is just far too long, even for someone (or something) as big as the big "G".

Rating: **1/2 out of 5.

review_title: A Godzilla movie without Godzilla
One word comes to mind.........LAME!!!!!
review_detailed_main: This movie had all the intelligence, acumen, forethought and necessity of, say...an orangutan using an adding machine. WOW, has Matthew Broderick's career folded faster than Superman on laundry day. Sadly enough...he was one of the BETTER actors here!!!

review_title: GODZILLA (1998) with Roger Ebert as mayor and Gene Siskel as his campaign assistant, HILARIOUS! WHAT A HOOT!!
Mediocre-ly OK
I understand the criticism but I still like this movie
review_detailed_main:
This movie (besides the Godzilla cartoon from the '70s) was the only Godzilla material I had access to (when I was a kid, back in the late 90s and early 2000s). I loved it back then and I still like it now.

Yes, Godzilla looks different. Yes, there are some goofy moments. Yes, there might be even some small plot holes. I don't deny any of this.

But in my opinion, Godzilla (1998) is very fun to watch (and kinda funny). The action is great, the pacing is good, Reno and Azaria are very likable and even the CGI is decent, if you compare it to today standards (back in the '90s, it was amazing)

Final rating: 8,3/10 (highly underrated action movie)

review_title: Apparently NOT for Fans of the Old, Cheesy Godzilla
review_detailed_main:
If you're a fan of the old Godzilla flicks, with lousy special effects, obvious cheap lizard suits and poorly detailed miniatures, you're apparently not going to like this movie, because the special effects are pretty good, despite a rather patent disregard for some basic laws of physics and moments of absolute abandonment of logic.

However, if you're not a dedicated fan of the old, bad Godzilla movies, you might just enjoy this new, bad Godzilla movie. This ain't Shakespeare, folks, but it's entertaining nevertheless. It's a crazy, campy, rampage through New York, where the "good guys" do almost as much damage as the real hero of the flick, Godzilla himself. The dialog is over the top, but often witty, and occasionally laugh-out-loud funny. Matthew Broderick turns in an entertaining performance as the nerdy anti-hero, aided by the enigmatic "insurance guy" played by Jean Reno, and an assortment of variously goofy lesser characters.

Don't expect a great plot, but if you give it a chance you might just be entertained.

review_title: Hit and miss.
review_detailed_main:
After scoring a huge hit with ID4 everyone expected Roland Emmerich to really impress us with this movie. Godzilla had a lot to live up to. It disappointed on every level imaginable. The only way to enjoy this is as purely brain-dead nonsense. Think about it and you'll realize how bad it is. So seriously, switch your brain off.

The problems mainly lie with the fact that Godzilla himself is very unremarkable. He's just a giant lizard. Hardly threatening. And like Matthew Broderick's character says, he's not evil-he just wants food. It's hard to consider him a baddie when all he does is accidentally trash New York. Plus he moves and looks too much like the Jurassic Park T-Rex to be particularly impressive.

None of the characters are interesting either. Which makes the 'character building' scenes completely useless. That time could have been put to much better use in this 140 minute long film. Only Jean Reno comes away with his dignity intact (can you believe he turned down playing Agent Smith to be in this?). Though it is cool to see Harry Shearer and Hank Azaria (Principal Skinner/Kent Brockman and Moe/Apu) in a movie together but they don't get much screen time.

In comparison to ID4, Emmerich's direction kind of falls flat. Remember the public reactions as huge spaceships descended upon New York and LA and how everyone kind of watched in hypnotical awe as panic arose around them. The same could have been used in Godzilla but far too much of the movie has New Yorkers acting completely indifferently to a 1000 foot reptile hopping through the city. And I know those Apache helicopter scenes featuring the 'miniature' buildings are supposed to be an homage to the Japanese Godzilla flicks but here they look completely stupid and seem like they belong in a different movie. They just don't fit in with the rest of the film and it's very distracting. That could have been handled a lot better.

The ending sets up story for two sequels which never happened because of massive audience disappointment. A shame kind of since Emmerich could have learned from his mistakes in this movie and made a sequel that is much better.

I own the Superbit DVD of Godzilla (only available in Region 2 at the moment) and the DTS 5.1 sound is awesome. With every pounding footstep of the big lizard the living room booms and shakes. Plus the 2.40:1 anamorphic picture is flawless.

review_title: Throwback blockbuster
review_detailed_main: This film was awesome back in the day but on repeat viewing it's not that great. Let's just say Godzilla is the best actor in it lol

review_title: The Worst Monster Flick Since King Kong(1976)
The problem was casting!
review_detailed_main: How could Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin create films such as Stargate and Independence day, and then somewhat fail with Godzilla. Watching it the third time last night I tried to analyze what I felt was wrong with the film. Everything is done to perfection when it comes to the technology behind making films. Godzilla looks great and all surroundings are professionally done (excluding the scene where three helicopters follow Godzilla between skyscrapers, which was too much like a computer game, with fake looking buildings). The story is not that badly written either. It is somewhat believable in the sense that the army is quick to respond, and work systematically to eliminate the problem. And the dialogs and character building is pretty good as well. So where is it that this film fails, because no one that I've spoken to has much good to say about Godzilla? I think it is the actors. If you think about Independence day we have Will Smith and Jeff Goldblum which carry the film through, complimenting all the CGI work and professionalism that went into that film. Same with Stargate where we have heavy weights like Kurt Russell and James Spader really making the film what it was. In Godzilla we lack that, as Matthew Broderick, while undoubtedly being a good actor, just isn't that larger-then-live character which was required for this sort of a film. He seems to kind a flounder from one scene to the next, never pulling of being the hero of the day. Same with Maria Pitillo, while being both beautiful and good actress, she seemed just as lost as Matthew in this part. And this can be seen when we have Jean Reno on the screen; the film pulls itself up and becomes interesting. He has that magic and is both believable and interesting. I also liked Hank Azaria, as the camera man trying to film the great story, while being more afraid of his wife then Godzilla. Godzilla is one of the best examples of how important casting is. Because without a doubt Godzilla had everything else working in its advance, while just lacking the thrust which powerful lead actors can give a film. 7/10

review_title: oh dear....
review_detailed_main:
Watched this and I must say I wasn't impressed.

It appeared to be lacking in just about every department excluding sfx of course. I was only watching it on a 14inch tv so that didn't do this flick much justice, but it was still...disappointing!!

Odd storyline, sort of non-storyline but then with flicks like this you dont really watch em for plot content, do ya??

I did find the holes in the plot as big as the Empire State Building, although I DID my best to ignore them! Stuff like this:

1) submarines in rivers shooting torpedos 2)helicoptors that fly forward not up to get away 3)huge 1000metre lizard hiding in subways 4)huge lizard laying hundreds of eggs in a building and going totally unnoticed 5)lizard travelling (i mean swimming) all the way to New York U. S. of A to lay its eggs...

the cliche list is endless!!

There was also a lot of Jurassic Park, Lost World etc so there went all sense of originality. From the makers of ID4, I am not surprised!

review_title: This is a FUN movie
review_detailed_main:
Everyone trashes this movie, but I thought it was good. I've always enjoyed creature features with large reptiles eating cities and Godzilla does does it very well.

If you want profound and serious, watch something else. If you want a "great" movie, watch something else. But if you want to spend a couple hours watching something FUN with no serious side effects, watch Godzilla. Bring in the kids, load up on popcorn and enjoy.

review_title: The Only Best Godzilla Film Ever Made
Not a bad movie!
A Plot less Piece of Trash
review_detailed_main:
Why did I expect anything from this movie? Roland Emmerich directed it. But the original Godzilla was just so good, why can't it ever stick true to the original 1954 version? This film was not what Godzilla was meant to be. A total disaster on most levels of quality. This truly is the Godzilla film that was never supposed to be made. Why the film was remade was beyond me, but it was just straight up bad.

There was no plot to the remake of the classic film we all know. It was basically meant to be based around the "new" design of the beast. There was nothing alike from the original Japanese version to the American remake. Godzilla was the beast, okay that's one thing but what else was there? If you are going to base a film off of another at least give a few names related to the first one. No names of characters were mentioned from the original. Nothing stuck true to the great original.

Godzilla in 1998 was strictly dedicated towards the use of CGI. The effects were impressive but the way Gojira was designed was nothing at all like the 1954 Gojira. Knowing Emmerich I knew there would be a tremendous amount of CGI involved, but there was so much that the plot became unbearable, well that is from what plot there ever was initially. Little to no plot was explained along with the origins of Godzilla like there was in the original.

The final thing that was poor about this film was the acting. Maria Pitillo was awful in this film. From her so called "crying" to, well everything else was just so bad. I don't know if it was just bad directing or if she was just naturally horrible. Either way, she was a bad choice for the role. Speaking of bad choices, why is Matthew Broderick in this? From his famous role as Ferris Bueller I never suspected he would be a scientist that is trying to stop a giant reptile.

The movie was just overall bad. It was a bit entertaining to say the most of it and there were impressive effects. But that isn't all a film needs to be good. Emmerich doesn't care about a film being good or bad. This film could be shot in red and yellow colouring and he still wouldn't care because he just wants to get money. Do NOT see this atrocious, plot less piece of garbage Emmerich considers a movie, even if the title draws your attention.

Just to sum it up, there was horrible acting and Godzilla didn't look anything alike what he did in 1954. Not to mention there is no plot whatsoever, kind of basing itself off of all the other ones and letting those story lines take its place. But the film is supposed to be a remake so it just throws a curve ball and if you haven't seen the original, well then you don't really have much of a chance when it comes to understanding what's going on half of the time.

review_title: LEAVE THE MOVIE ALONE, IT'S NOT THAT BAD.
review_detailed_main: I liked this movie, sure it had some cliches and the acting sucked, but it was still an effective action movie that definitely delivered, what's wrong with that. Whoever has a problem with this movie, feel free to e-mail me and tell me, but you'd be wasting your time and mine, because you're wrong if you think that this movie is the worst of the year. -*** stars

review_title: A Tremendous Spectacle and Nothing More
review_detailed_main:
Firmly in the pile of movies that I can confess to liking but understanding the hate, 'Godzilla' is a strong piece of work in set design and cinematography; I really like the aesthetic and lighting throughout.

Matthew Broderick should never be cast as the main character, and really struggles. Maria Pitillo is also finding it tough but performs a little better. Hank Azaria is enticing and actually very good. Jean Reno can do no wrong but his character is underwritten.

The overall direction is a mixed bag. While the practical and physical effects are stunning for the most part, the story and emotional character writing is hampered by poor actor direction and some careless dialogue execution.

review_title: If you pretend it's a Beast from 20,000 Fathoms remake it's not terrible
review_detailed_main:
Following a series of A-Bomb tests conducted in French Polynesia, an Iguana nest is exposed to the radiation. Sometime later a fishing vessel is attacked by a large reptilian creature whose sole survivor only says "Gojira". Dr. Nick Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick), a biologist working for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission specializing in radioactive mutations in animals, is reassigned from his current position to examine the wreckage of the fishing vessel in Panama and the near by claw marks. The creature heads to New York City where Audrey Timmonds (Maria Pitillo), Nick's ex and an aspiring reporter is hoping to move up from assistant to journalist and be free of her sexist boss Charles Caiman (Harry Shearer). Nick and his military team try to find a way of stopping the creature and stop its swath of destruction.

Godzilla is a well-known property with its films being a staple of video rental stores and TV airings for a number of years. Attempts had been made to create a Hollywood adaptation of the Japanese kaiju staple since the 80s with Friday the 13th Part 2 and 3 director Steve Miner's pitch for Godzilla: King of the Monsters in 3D getting some interest but Miner's lack of experience beyond low budget but very successful slashers made financiers weary of such a project. The next iteration happened in the early 90s which almost became the directorial debut of cinematographer Jan de Bont of Die Hard and Basic instinct and would've featured Godzilla as a relic of Atlantean engineering who was destined to protect humanity from a shapeshifting creature called the Gryphon. Sony refused to approve the $100-120 million production budget which caused the project to fall apart. Sony then approached Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich prior to the release of Independence Day and agreed on the condition that it would be on their terms and Sony agreed giving them a $150 million budget. Emmerich and Devlin taking control is where the project was pretty much doomed because interviews between the two with various sources have them saying things like Godzilla was a "dopey idea", they weren't interested in "two monsters going at it", or "We forgot everything about the original Godzilla right there" just to name a few stand out lines of how much "passion" the two had for the project down to the fact the two wanted to do away with Godzilla's iconic fire breath only for fan outrage to force them at the 11th hour to add the barely noticeable flames in two sequences in the film. Godzilla is not a good Godzilla movie, and that can be traced to the fact it's made by two guys who don't like Godzilla as a concept. But taking out the "Godzilla" factor, Godzilla 1998 is simply a middle of the road 90s creature feature trying to capture the feeling of Jurassic Park.

Much like Devlin and Emmerich's previous films Stargate and Independence Day, their tropes are in full force here. Awkward nerd protagonist? Check! Clandestine military operation? Check? Conspiracy/cover-up? Check! Broad caricatures filling out the ensemble cast? Well, three voice actors from The Simpsons are in the movie so what do you think? Unlike Independence Day however, there are no big names in the cast so Godzilla can't bank off the credibility and charisma of its actors like Independence Day did. While Mathew Broderick was a staple throughout 80s pop culture, he was considerably less so in the 90s with his voice work in the back half of The Lion King probably his best work until he'd do the Alexander Payne adaptation of Election in 1999 (along with Inspector Gadget, but that's neither here nor there). Outside of Broderick, French actor Jean Reno was probably the most well known figure in the cast having appeared in the great Luc Besson thriller Leon: The Professional, but hardly a household name to sell the movie on. That's probably why the marketing for Godzilla tended to keep its cast close to the vest with marketing materials on buses, billboards, and Taco-Bell ads focusing mostly on the size of Godzilla's foot rather than any kind of story because the name does most of the work with a property like this. But of course when your movie fails to deliver what people want from a Godzilla movie, the goodwill of the franchise only carries so far.

Emmerich and Devlin's biggest mistake is in straying so far from the original interpretation. Even in the worst Godzilla movies Godzilla is still shown as an unstoppable force who only moves forward, in Godzilla 1998 the Godzilla runs away from military hardware instead of acting like its unphased by it. The design of Godzilla would be fine if this were a remake of Beast from 20,000 Fathoms, but with this large headed flat topped lizard with tiny eyes supposed to be Godzilla it's pretty underwhelming and looks and feels more like a deformed T-Rex model from Jurassic Park. Even the tone of the movie isn't quite sure how to approach Godzilla because at one point during the "fish bait" scene where they lure Godzilla with fish, Broderick's character is face to face with Godzilla and the music by David Arnold seems like it's almost going for wonder like the scene in Jurassic Park where we first see a dinosaur, this confusion over how to handle Godzilla goes right to the climax where it seems like it's trying to be as somber as the ending of King Kong from 1933 while also having the rousing "victory" feelings of Independence Day. I'd also be remised if I didn't mention the half hearted Siskel and Ebert satire where a character named Mayor Ebert and his sniveling yes-man Gene prat about the movie doing nothing but invoking the "Thumbs Up" imagery from their syndicated review series. Siskel and Ebert panned Stargate and Independence Day and I guess this is Devlin and Emmerich's idea of "so there!".

In terms of Box Office Garbage, Godzilla isn't offensively awful or anything. It does give monster rampages that you can see and follow. Granted it's not all the great but it's still head and shoulders above 1998's top grossing film Armageddon by virtue of being A) Shorter and B) watchable without getting motion sickness. It's pretty much a reskin of Independence Day only with a giant lizard in place of flying saucers, and the same tropes you saw in Stargate and Independence Day.

review_title: Boring (need I say more?)
review_detailed_main: Okay, you got me; I guess I do have more to say than that. I'll tell you what's bad in here: everything. It was so long that I almost fell asleep, the writing sounded like it was done in 1 day or less, the acting was terrible (well, I'll cut Matthew Brodrick a little slack), but, oh no, do you want to know about what distracted me the most? It was definitely the special effects. Trust me, the effects were *so* sloppy, it looked like that a super-computer had gone all bonkers and a character from cyberspace is trying to attack Manhattan. Plus, the sounds that went with it should have went with a wild animal, *not* an over-sized Dinosauer. The bottom line: skip it. If I see it one more time, I'm gonna fall flat on my face.

review_title: Has good moments but ultimately a real disappointment
It's not meant to be a triumph, just meant to entertain, and that's what it did.
review_detailed_main: This was a good, not great, but good movie. I thought the special effects were terrific, and the humor, action, and sound was great. All-in-all, an entertaining popcorn movie, that's big, loud, and fun. 7 out of 10.

review_title: Another bad movie by Devlin and Emmerich
review_detailed_main: To put it mildly, this movie stinks worse than limberger cheese. It's too long, the dialogue is contrived, Matthew Broderick went on acting holiday and whoever wrote this must of have been drunk. The special effects were fantastic though with the Creature and all that but seriously I've seen Japanese versions of Godzilla with just as much credibility and believability as this load of nonsense. In all of it's 2 and a half or so hours about ten minutes is good, the parts with creature(s) but that is all. Devlin has been quoted as saying that he wrote ID4 in four days, my question is did he write this in one of his lunch breaks? If you want to see a good funny monster type movie rent Lake Placid.

review_title: God that was long
Should have called it Jurassic Park
review_detailed_main: I heard many bad reviews about this film.. considering it was the first American adaptation of Godzilla. Everybody is getting geared up for the show..but it just a f..King disaster movies from the start till the end. I gave it two star because of two reason one of them is imdb don't have a zero star rating and another star is because of the only song I finds it entertaining come with me by Puff Daddy and Jimmy Page.

review_title: Needs improvement, but a good first try.
review_detailed_main: I'd like to consider myself a devoted fan of Godzilla, as I love the classic movies. While this new one falls short of deserving such revere, I do believe all the negative reviews are uncalled for. True, some of the casting left a lot to be desired (Pitillo and Broderick come to mind). But this Godzilla movie does something that NONE of the classic one did. It shows Godzilla as a creature, not a monster bent on creating havoc. As with all creature-features it's only natural to root for the decline of humanity at the claws of nature's creation. But here we're shown two creatures, humans and Godzilla, how are striving to survive. Humans attack Godzilla because he's (or she's) destroying our homes and businesses. Godzilla only attacks out of self defense, and later out of revenge over the death of its young. Aside from the National Geographic aspects, the special effects deserve an Oscar nomination, if not Oscar himself. Godzilla looked and behaved in a believable manner. Not since Jurassic Park has this occurred. One final note, for a 'pitiful, weak story' GODZILLA is in the top-five take of 1998's summer grosses. Roland and Dean, if you do a sequel as planned, really reconsider casting.

review_title: It ain't THAT bad
It's got a few issues but still a great film!
review_detailed_main:
Now. I will first off admit I'm biased. I've been watching this film since I was a toddler and that makes me biased. But I will admit it's got issues. IMO it's main issue is with the titular character of course. I'm a huge Godzilla fan. Always have been, and I've seen every film. So the biggest issue is that Godzilla is too vulnerable and ran away too much at times. If that were changed at least half the criticism would go away but I digress. Other then that I think it's a great monster film/disaster film. I think it has a good cast and good story. Good action and effects and all. The human cast was one of the more memorable and well done ones in the Godzilla franchise IMO.

Overall I find this to be a film that despite it's issues with Godzilla's characterization is a fun film to watch. It has a good story and cast of characters. Alongside plenty of good monster action and all! I especially love watching it on a rainy day.

review_title: 3 words to say
review_detailed_main:
ACTING

DOES

MATTER

review_title: Lower case g "godzilla"
review_detailed_main:
I remember actually liking this when I was younger. It had such great marketing too, I remember the Taco Bell dog quipping off the giant gecko, I remember getting a drink holder shaped like the lizard's claw, the toys were everywhere... It was fun!

Oh how things have changed.

This movie is bad. It's flirting with "so bad it's good" territory but no, it's just bad. The lizard looks ridiculous now, the performances are awful almost all around, save for Reno and Azaria. The comedy is just stupid and the movie makes no sense as it desperately claws for every bit of low hanging fruit it can get at. The movie is flat out stupid at numerous points, but it takes itself so seriously.

Azaria is enjoyable and Reno is doing the best he can to turn garbage into gold. They are the only positives here beyond the occasional dumb joke that does manage to hit that "so bad it's good" spot but they are free and far between.

Can't really recommend this for anyone. Fans of actual Godzilla movies seem to universally hate it. It's not a good action movie, there's no real drama, no performance worth seeing, no technical achievement. It's aged horribly in every possible way. Steer clear.

review_title: It was great when I was 10...
"Oh, no! They say he's got to go . . . "
Fun and Creative!
review_detailed_main: While watching Godzilla, I felt that the director had fun with the material. I know a lot of people, namely Godzilla fans, always daydreamed or imagined Godzilla chasing a cab around the Big Apple, and that's what we got, in a very satisfying way. I felt Godzilla did everything I would have wanted him to do. The movie was a bit more satisfying than "The Lost World: Jurassic Park". Although the movie does have it's faults: the characters aren't interesting, and the cab chase, although very enjoyable, seems out of place. When Godzilla first arrives in New York, it's interesting how Emmerich uses the camera to film his arrival. Only showing his legs. It's a great touch. In the end, I was satisfied with the action and the special effects (way better than Independence Day's, although ID4 was a bit more enjoyable), but not with the characters. *** out of ****.

review_title: This was the end of movies as we knew them.
Watch Out New York! Here Comes Minor Nuisance, Zilla!
review_detailed_main:
I don't like discussing Roland Emmerich films for the most part. It's very easy to describe why he's bad in a way that millions have already done. I'll get into how I would describe his sort of style or schtick later, but I definitely dislike it, and this movie detracts for those reasons. But it's not just those Emmerich-isms that make this movie not work.

This movie is interestingly quite different from the other stuff he does. I think it's for that reason that this movie gets such a bad wrap even among people who are more forgiving of, say, Independence Day or Day After Tomorrow. The people who like this movies like the sort of simplicity and spectacle of all this destruction. But there's key differences that ruin what those people might want, for example;


The thing about this is, it amplifies a lot of the stupid in Roland Emmerich movies. In Independence Day, for example, I find a lot of the characters paper thin as they are here. But there are fifty million of them in that movie, and you don't really need them to be fleshed out. Here you just have a handful, and you spend a lot of time with them. In a lot of RE movies he picks one quirk for a character which is okay when the character only appears a few times. But when its the French character who just complains about coffee it becomes frustrating when we get so much from a character who has so little behind him. And then we get so much military plans and discussions and planning, which is so stupid and uninteresting. And like, I'm never particularly interested, because the way the movie feels a giant lizard occupying a city of 20 million never feels that big a threat.

It's all so odd that they've made these mistakes because you have a really easy movie for him. Godzilla seems like the perfect fit for RE's sort of movies, just have him go out and destroy all these cities and have the US try to find a way to blow him up. Easy. The thing is though, RE actually hates Godzilla movies, from what I have read. He thinks they are stupid and silly, which, I don't know, have a bit of self awareness mate? He didn't like the design of the original Godzilla, calling him "fat", wanting this reptile thing in the movie. I don't despise the redesign, excluding the gigachad chin. The thing is for me is that Godzilla should be terrifying, the sort of thing where you look out your window and you see this hulking menace and you know you're screwed. For whatever reason he just has Godzilla burrow underground and lay eggs, he barely hurts anyone. Everyone he kills is either by accident, or after they attacked him first. So we have this threat who, honestly isn't that threatening. Am I supposed to be frightened?

Godzilla in this movie is just like a lizard thing that only cares about eating and laying eggs. There is something you can do with that, and I don't mean to say that being different is inherently bad. I like the idea that he's not particularly evil or dangerous but as a giant animal has the potential to cause great harm at any point. Except, they barely delve into that, so they didn't even replace it for an interesting replacement. Same goes for the audio design - they removed the iconic roar and replaced it with what I think is elephant sounds, which once I figured that out couldn't imagine this movie with any level of seriousness. But even if it wasn't a bad audio design, why change it? You have a perfectly good audio cue, if you're going to replace it, you should find a good sound at the very least. I can imagine a better version of this movie, where they focus on Godzilla who comes up every now and then to tear down factories of meat or stores and stuff. He's not a walking tank like the Japanese movies, but he is genuinely terrifying, and there is this fear that every so often he could just jump back out and cause damage so the military really need to find him.

I can't say that I would expect that from Roland Emmerich. He has this reputation as making dumb movies, but they aren't just dumb. I mean you can call a movie dumb because their aren't themes or interesting plot points, but that doesn't mean the movie can't be great. You need a filmmaker who is able to direct a scene in a way in which we feel the impact and excitement of an action set piece. When Godzilla springs out and five hundred helicopters come out to chasing him, I'm not just thinking how stupid it all is. I'm thinking, why is there no weight to this, why does this all just feel like noise? This is how I feel about a lot of his movies, especially in 2012, where you see all this destruction, which has great VFX. But there's no real threat, no feeling that anyone's in danger. I don't see the scene with helicopters running past and cross my fingers hoping they'll blast Godzilla. Instead it's just like, visual noise. It looks okay. But it's not engaging.

And it also is so strange that Roland Emmerich makes these dumb movies because not only can he never direct it with any engaging set pieces, he has no creativity. You have the free reign to create whatever set piece, environment you want, and it's all in drab rainy New York. You can have Godzilla do whatever he wants, but all he does is go after fish and lay some eggs, he has no interesting powers beyond fire breathing which was literally added last minute to address fans criticising the lack of atomic breath. And my god, somebody really liked Jurassic Park. While I don't think Godzilla's design is aping Spielberg, a lot of the shots are. The whole, keep it dark and rainy for better shots, and especially a lot of the shots early on remind me of the end of Lost World. I think it's fine to be inspired by Spielberg. But you should have something original and cool happen.

review_title: That's a lot of fish
review_detailed_main:
This is not a very good film, the story is weak, the acting is wooden and the fish are a plenty, in fact you may say there are a lot of them, and this is one thing the films delivers on.

So if you like your giant monsters movies to have heart pumping action, suspense filled scenes, great acting and fantastic special effects, give this film a wide berth.

If you like a lot of fish, then this film has fish, a lot of fish.

Review - 4 fish down

review_title: What did you expect ?
review_detailed_main: I voted 8 for this movie and that may surprise you. The reason is very clear : I went to see this movie not for the great actors (hard to find) not for the great dialogues (where ?) but for the great special effects created by Sony Pictures. I combination with the Sony Dynamic Digital Sound system (AKA SDDS) the result was superb.(PS.: I'm not a Sony employee if you might think that...)

review_title: Deal With It!
review_detailed_main: Hey all: This movie was not made to have the greastet plot, be deep and emotional and whatnot. It was made for fun viewing of a big lizard destroying NY city. And it did what it was intended. There will always be people saying how bad a movie is, and give reasons. If you didnt like, thats fine; join the crowd. If you did, alright, good for you. I thought that it wasnt a bad film, although it did rip-off 'Jurassic Park' in many scenes ('JP' is my fav movie). Anyway, a movie is supposed to be entertaining, and those of you that went to se with low expetations just made it that much worse. So, all there is left to say is: DEAL WITH IT!

review_title: Only bearable at the time for the special effects
Brains Matter, Too
And you thought Garfield Gets Real was bad
Plainly silly and horrible
review_detailed_main:
I didn't want to see this movie because I have heard and read too many bad things about Godzilla. But anyway, I watched it yesterday. The movie was so stupid and boring, what I can't find enough words to describe it. The plot was incredible lame, love story between Dr. Tatoupolos and Audrey so weak! But, more importantly, whole cast team looks incredibly poor. I really wonder, how Rolland Emmerich, who directed Stargate, Independence Day and The Patriot (not a great movies but highly entertained and well shot) could make so bad movie. Watch Jurassic Park movies (second and third of course not so good as first but they are at least watchable) or original King-Kong instead. Not recommend to anyone, except huge fans of monster's movies. Maybe they can find something interesting in this true disappointment. Personally I suppose that Godzilla is a strong candidate for worst movie of the year and excellent example that visual effects without good story and acting mean only waste of money and nothing more.

My vote: plot 3, cast 3, sound 5, visual effects 6, stupidity 9 - overall 3,5/10 Thanks for reading.

review_title: In 98' People Took This Film Way Too Seriously
review_detailed_main:
There once was a Godzilla story...... From a Long Time Ago - NOW (2023) And None Of Them EVER Ever Have Delivered To It's Audience A Whole Lotta Epic Seriousness. I was 8 years old when this American Zilla Film (1998) was Released. I have Watched the Originals With Subtitles & Black and White and None of those movies have ever been shown with Serious Monuments of Hardcore plot lines.... When the Originals Clearly portray All Monsters there-in Dancing Jigs and Communicating with each other about how stupid people are, including the Singing Mothara Twins.

This being said ...... In my opinion, as I watch this Film again after seeing it Several times since it's release date..... Ya'll Forget how comical the originals were and it was done on purpose.

Why would the American film be so naive to overlook this kind of detailed work from older films from overseas. Keep in mind it's art not exacted science this business of creating entertainment.

I Personally LOVE this version of Godzilla and With how popular the Godzilla: Series was as the film's follow-up.

I think it be Amazing to Now Create A New Godzilla Film series that Recreates Those Shorts since they were praised so much After the fact of the series ending.

review_title: Below my lowest expectations
review_detailed_main:
First, I should explain that I'm not really expecting much from a film that is basically an Americanized CGI update of a man in a rubber reptile suit stomping on toy buildings and tanks. But based on what Mssrs. Devlin and Emmerich have delivered, I'll take repeat viewings of the old Japanese movies any day. Even the bad ones, like "Godzilla on Monster Island ".

Let's just take this point by point:

1) Characters with no personality

2) A monster with even less personality

3) Can somebody explain to me what was supposed to be so funny about the Ebert and Siskel characters?

4) Ending stolen directly from DeLaurentis' "King Kong" - note to Dean and Roland - if you're going to borrow, at least borrow from a GOOD flick!

Final assessment: If there is a plan for a sequel, let's just give it to Schumacher. Based on how he tanked the Batman sequels, he would be a natural for the benchmark set by this garbage.

review_title: Main Titles are good
review_detailed_main: I haven't seen this since it played in theaters in 1998, but if memory serves me right, the title sequence was low-key and evocative, very well-done. But after that, the picture goes way down. Matthew Broderick is miscast horrendously as a heroic type, and Maria Pitillo is a terrible actress, playing an absurd character. As in "Independence Day", the producers start off with the attack, so that there's nothing really to climax. The Japanese Godzilla and his ilk and all those wonderful 1950s monster mashes always had the delirious rampages in the final acts. The film has an annoying rainstorm in New York City during most of the proceedings, and is almost always at night. Is this to cover up inadequate CGI effects? The trailer seen months before had the famous Godzilla roar, but here he looks or sounds NOTHING like the Japanese classic dragon/tyrannosaurus/stegosaurus. The creature breathes no fire, makes little sounds or even tramples buildings. He even disappears half-way through the film! The climax is assinine since a taxi can not outrun a 200-foot animal. Dreadful.

review_title: Ferris Bueler's Day At Work!
review_detailed_main:
So back in the days when Matthew Broderick was still cute and before CGI took over completely, they made this film which wasn't entirely done in front of a blue screen and I think it's a relative success. It's a "Type" of film that up until now I have only ever seen bits of, but enough to cobble together what was going on. That's what makes it work for me, the fact that you don't need to pay a huge amount of attention, but you are rewarded with some great scenes of a monster terrorising New York when you do look at the screen or come back from the kitchen. Would we call him a monster? I think that's a bit harsh actually and according to this film he is, what we as a people, have made him. I don't think he does it deliberately.

Having now watched it all the way through, it makes even more sense and I would be happy to tune in again. It is a much more accessible 'Godzilla' than the 2014 version, even though my husband Aaron Taylor Johnson is in that one.

The only thing that I think really complicates issues here is that there are so many characters involved. I think that they could have made the same film without at least the Mayor, Harry Shearer's news anchor and Hank Azaria (A severely underrated actor), the cameraman's wife and still achieved the same results.

It's not that it's overly long because of it, but it does get very busy on the screen at times.

The CGI and the animatronics work well together. I'm actually more of a fan of models and people in rubber masks or make up than I am of CGI anyway, but I understand how much better films are because of it now.

It's not an offensive film and it doesn't raise political questions and it's not trying to get a message across, but it's fun and simple to follow.

review_title: A Dreadful Remake
review_detailed_main: I suppose there are sometimes valid reasons for remaking classic movies. Whatever the reason was for this remake, though - it was definitely the wrong reason! This is truly atrocious in almost every way. The acting wasn't great (although I'll admit that Matthew Broderick seemed to be trying his best even while he wasn't being especially convincing), the script was weak, and there was too much of an attempt to make this a sort-of comedy, with lame bits of humour being thrown in that to be honest weren't really all that funny. It's hard to figure out how this went wrong. You have a huge dinosaur wreaking havoc in New York City! That, by the way, caused me confusion. Why did Godzilla make this trek from the Pacific, through the Panama Canal and to New York City? Was that ever explained? If it was, I missed it. But at the very least, Godzilla in New York City alone should be fun. But it wasn't. This turned out to be the sort of movie I'd glance at every few minutes to see if I had missed anything - and I'd immediately realize that I hadn't missed a thing. It was just an all round poor production. Based on the look of Godzilla and some of the effects I'd guess this was kind of inspired by the success of Jurassic Park a few years earlier, but it was lacking in spark. I'd really be tempted to give this a 1/10, but given that there have been other remakes of "Godzilla" since that I haven't seen, I'll give this a 2 and leave the 1 available, just in case one of the more recent remakes is even worse - although it's hard to believe that would be possible.

review_title: And settle for less? I think not.
review_detailed_main:
First off, you'll read lots of critiques ranging from people who are purists of the Gojira franchise to those with less expectations for a monster movie. I've read some reviews here that sound frustrated about purists not being satisfied. They want them to accept the movie for what it was. A special effects laden movie and nothing more.

Well.. I'm going to say one word followed by reason. "NO"

Gojira fans deserve much better for a movie that claimed itself to be the revolution of Godzilla just because of its use of amazing CGI.

This movie bombed. Pure and simple. It sucked and you will have more agree to that than the otherwise. The film director took a beloved creature which was created in Japan based off of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima. Radioactive residue turning a lizard into a mutant giant monster.

The sole idea here, was that the monster was basically created by our stupidity with warfare activities that took place a long time ago. Something that emerged from our wrong doings. A giant monster karma of a problem to put it in short words. This monster wasn't evil. But it had the instincts of an enraged creature seeking exploration of its surroundings and clashing with humans for the second time.

The film, Godzilla 1985 (Gojira 1984 in japans aka Gojira Returns), pretty much successfully set that idea and created a very respected, inspiring and intense movie that was ahead of its own time. The 80s.

This new American Godzilla film however, changed and denied 80% of the original creator's intention and turned our beloved monster into gargantuan mush.

And for those who are saying "who cares, its just a monster movie", you're a disgrace to the G-fan base whether you care so or not. Therefore your sub-standard ideals about movie quality no longer hold weight to me.

I'm the kind of person that pushes a job until it cant be pushed no more. I'm all about top notch quality. Not just visual quality, but EVERYTHING quality. Story had to be much better than this nonsense. It could have been good. Really good. But it really wasn't. It just wasn't. The special effects, amazing in its own respect to the artists behind them, did not aid the movies direction. The major disrespectful approach to change an iconic monster into a chicken legged giant iguana, really let a lot of fans down and with good reason as that thing just wasn't God'fricken'zilla.

However... had the film been renamed to its actual now fan labeled name "Zilla", I would have not had been received as badly. Dropping any expectations and possibly even appreciating this movie only as a second rate monster movie. Which would probably have helped it in terms of reputation.

And yes, I do understand that this monster is no longer called Godzilla in Japan either. It is now known ONLY as "Zilla" by the Japanese. It was so iffy, they couldn't take in what the American bought license did to their beloved monster. I mean, let's be honest. When the news first leaked out about an American release of Godzilla, we were all hyped up expecting that same powerful iconic nostalgic feeling we got in the 80's when Godzilla first hit Hollywood theaters. IT WAS HUGE NEWS!

Thats why many including I, feel this movie was a let down. Quality is everything. As a creator myself, I live by those words. If you adapt to low quality or moderate quality and tell yourself "it was good"... then you will never taste the fruit of a truly great quality production. And Im not going to discuss the Japanese G movies as those were understandably being made on low budgets. What do you expect with little money. :/ But for an American film, I really expected something that would have embedded itself in my memories as well as the memories of our kids today. Sort of like what Godzilla 1985 was back then.

Alas, not this time. My chime. And Im sticking to it.

review_title: What was in those critics minds, when they saw this movie?
review_detailed_main: Look, I loved this move, I heard by the critics it stunk, but I never listen to the critics, if you haven't see this movie see it, don't listen to what people tell you decide on it yourself.

review_title: One of the worst movies I ever watched
review_detailed_main:
Let's be honest. It didn't help that Matthew Broderick got the main role here.

Continuing with the truth, no one could have helped this abomination of a film.

I watched this movie back in the day while being underage, and I already thought that it was terrible. If it couldn't appeal to a non-adult, I can't image how anybody except for the brain dead can find this interesting.

I hope the 2014 movie of the same name goes as far away as possible as what they made here.

review_title: What a disgrace to real movie making and real acting!!!!
review_detailed_main:
The only reason I didn't leave the theater half way through this horrible movie was because I rode with my friend who actually wanted to stay and finish it out. To this day I cannot believe that Matthew Broderick is the same actor who gave us Ferris Bueller's Day Off. This guy hasn't done anything worth watching since then.

Let me just state for the record, that hollywood couldn't have made a dumber looking godzilla than what they put in this one. And the mickey mouse plot was about enough to make me want to vomit for actually willingly giving away $6.25 of my money to see this worthless piece of work. I haven't seen a more predictable, overly dramatic plot using overly dramatic theme music (which was oh so annoying) since I saw Twister.

I thought that Godzilla was supposed to have a cult following. I respect movies or actors that have earned those followers, hence the reason I wanted to see Godzilla. I had never really watched a godzilla flick from beginning to end before, so I figured I'd go to this one to see what the hype was about. I have rarely been as disappointed in my movie going life as I was on this day. Other movies that are comparable to this in terms of how poor and disappointing the movie was are in my mind Twister, Armegeddon, Scream 2 and 3, and Jurassic Park 3.

Honestly I wouldn't sit through this movie again even if Hollywood offered to double my money back. Just horrible.

review_title: Not for Godzilla fans
review_detailed_main:
I didn't like this movie at all words cannot describe how disappointed I was. I was expecting to see a Godzilla with good CGI special effects who breathed nuclear fire his main attribute. No fire, he didn't sound like the original and he didn't even look like the original. The only think I liked better was the special effects. The guy in the suit was cheesy looking but the movies were more entertaining.

I don't know what they were thinking when they made this but they didn't have old school Godzilla fans in mind. This is more like a lame attempt to beat people out of their money and make a quick buck. I suppose if you didn't grow up watching the original you may enjoy it I think expecting an improve version of the original may have killed it for folks. For old school fans don't waste your time.

review_title: Oh, common
review_detailed_main:
I'll hop right into it now.

As a "Godzilla" movie it's total crap, Godzilla looks like some sort of screwed-up dinosaur, not like Godzilla must look. And it totally lacks the funny styrofoam look and strange stories of the original movies. I gotta say this as a true Godzilla (the original movies) fan.

On the other hand it deserves some points for good effects, action and some suspense.

All in all it's fun watching once (but not as a Godzilla movie) but that's it

review_title: Roland Emmerich is a blithering incompetent
review_detailed_main:
Oh sure, he can put purty pitchers on the screen, but he has not the slightest idea of how to actually make those images into a movie (just for that asinine in-joke about "Ebert" and "Gene," Emmerich should be forbidden ever to get near a film camera again).

Listening to the moronic and implausible dialogue in GODZILLA, one wonders if Emmerich or his collaborators have ever spent five minutes talking to actual human beings. They are clearly far more interested in big CGI lizards and things going boom, and they can't even get those things right (the CGI, though technically impressive, does not look at all real).

Think of all the films Wes Anderson could have made with this one crappy movie's budget, and weep.

review_title: An enjoyable film to waste an afternoon with
review_detailed_main:
There is no reason to castigate the producers of what is essentially just a sci-fi monster movie for being unable to create a cinematic masterpiece out of this material. It was enjoyable and had some good lines.
